Admiralty Court: What it is, How it Works, History
By
Will Kenton
Full Bio
Will Kenton is an expert on the economy and investing laws and regulations. He previously held senior editorial roles at Investopedia and Kapitall Wire and holds a MA in Economics from The New School for Social Research and Doctor of Philosophy in English literature from NYU.
Learn about our
editorial policies
Updated June 07, 2022
Reviewed by
Andy Smith
Reviewed by
Andy Smith
Full Bio
Andy Smith is a Certified Financial Planner (CFP®), licensed realtor and educator with over 35 years of diverse financial management experience. He is an expert on personal finance, corporate finance and real estate and has assisted thousands of clients in meeting their financial goals over his career.
Learn about our
Financial Review Board
Close
What Is an Admiralty Court?
An admiralty court is a tribunal with jurisdiction over maritime law, including cases regarding shipping, ocean, and sea laws. Historically, admiralty courts were a separate part of the court system. In modern times, these cases may be assigned within the regular court system, usually at the federal or Superior Court level.
In the U.S., any court that is hearing a maritime case is an admiralty court for the duration of that case.
Understanding the Admiralty Court
An admiralty court hears shipping, ocean, and sea legal cases. The definition of such cases is broad, encompassing contracts,
torts
, injuries, and offenses relating to maritime law and events that occur on the high seas.
Key Takeaways
An admiralty court hears a wide range of cases related to maritime law.
In the U.S., any federal court may be designated an admiralty court for the purposes of the case under consideration.
Cases heard in admiralty court are generally civil, not criminal.
The courts thus hear a range of cases covering
shipping
, boating, insurance matters related to ships or their cargo, collisions at sea, civil matters involving seamen, passengers, and cargo, salvage claims, claims for damages by ships, disputed ownership of ships, and even marine pollution cases.
Generally, modern admiralty courts hear civil actions, not criminal cases.
Admiralty courts have the power to issue a maritime lien against a ship, allowing the court or its appointees to seize the ship to settle claims against it.
Whether it can be seized in other countries is governed by the admiralty courts of those countries and also is subject to any treaties that may be in effect among the nations involved.
History of Admiralty Courts
Admiralty courts date back to the mid-14th century in England. At that time, they were under the jurisdiction of Navy admirals, hence the name.
Much later, regional Vice-Admiralty courts were established across the British Empire to resolve commercial disputes between merchants and seamen. During wartimes, their powers were expanded to deal with such matters as impounded enemy ships and criminal smuggling operations.
In the U.S., the founders envisaged from the start that federal courts would have jurisdiction over admiralty law since maritime matters often involved questions of national importance. This point is enshrined in the
U.S. Constitution
.
Important
The admiralty court has its origins in 14th century England. The judges were admirals.
Jurisdiction for matters that once fell under admiralty courts has been given over to regular court systems in most modern countries, usually at the federal or Superior Court level.
In Canada, the jurisdiction resides with the Federal Court. In the U.K. the Admiralty Court is now one part of the Business and Property Court under the High Court.
To this day, when such courts hear matters relating to admiralty law they will be referred to as admiralty courts. In the U.S., when federal courts act as admiralty courts, they operate under unique maritime law rules and do not impanel juries. The cases are heard by a judge.

60-Year-Olds’ Average 401(k) Balance
How Much Do You Need to Retire?
How to Boost Retirement Savings
Average 401(k) Balance for People in Their 60s in 2026—What You Need to Know
By
Katharine Paljug
Full Bio
Katharine Paljug is a financial writer and editor with over a decade of industry experience. Her writing has covered nearly every aspect of the financial world, from investing in forex to paying for college, and she specializes in presenting complex financial topics in an accessible way to non-experts.
Learn about our
editorial policies
Published January 11, 2026
You can boost your savings by downsizing now instead of in retirement, taking advantage of higher catch-up contributions in your 60s, and reallocating assets to prioritize growth.
Patricio Nahuelhual / Getty Images
Close
Key Takeaways
The average 401(k) balance for people in their 60s was $568,040 as June 2025. The median amount saved was much lower, at $188,792.
How much you need to have saved for retirement will depend on your lifestyle and annual spending expectations. One rule of thumb is to save eight times your annual preretirement income by age 60.
When you hit your 60s and retirement is right around the corner, you might find yourself thinking a lot about your 401(k). How does what you have saved compare to other people your age? And how much do you really need for retirement?
While it can be
tempting to compare your savings
to your peers, how much you need to have saved will depend on when you plan to retire and what you want that retirement to look like.
401(k) Savings in Your 60s: The Average and Median Balances Explained
According to Empower, the average
401(k)
balance for someone in their 60s was $568,040 as of June 2025.
This balance was slightly lower than the $607,055 average 401(k) balance for those in their 50s, presumably because some people in their 60s have already retired and begun taking distributions from their 401(k).
Keep in mind that averages can be easily skewed: just a few 401(k)s with very high (or very low) balances can drastically impact the average. That's why the
median
or middle-of-the-road figure is important. The median amount in June 2025 was $188,792.
Related Stories
Retirement Savings Secret Revealed: How One Overlooked Account Can Boost Your Nest Egg
Don’t Risk Retirement Funds to Pay Debt: Key Mistakes to Avoid
How Much Do You Need to Retire?
If you’re looking at these numbers and worrying about
how your own retirement savings compare
, you’re not alone. According to a survey by Western & Southern Financial Group, 47% of
Baby Boomers
(who make up the majority of those in their 60s, as the oldest members of
Generation X
turn 60 in 2025) are not confident in their ability to retire comfortably. Another 11% of Baby Boomers are unsure whether they'll be able to retire comfortably.
The same survey clearly identified why: Baby boomers believe they need an average of $760,000 saved to retire comfortably. Gen X expects to need even more: $1.18 million.
Average and median 401(k) savings for those in their 60s are far below these amounts.
However, how much you need to retire depends on a variety of factors, particularly your lifestyle and your health. Rather than looking solely at averages, it’s helpful to look at your personal situation to determine how much you need to save.
One retirement savings rule suggests having eight times your preretirement annual income saved by age 60.
So if you make $75,000 per year, you would need $600,000 saved by age 60.
Another calculation is based on
the 4% rule
, which suggests that retirees withdraw 4% of their 401(k) in their first year of retirement, then adjust this for inflation in each following year.
Following this rule would mean you need to have 25 times your annual expenses saved. So if you expect to spend $36,000 a year in retirement, you will need to have $900,000 saved.
Keep in mind that most retirees don’t live on their 401(k) alone. Most retirees in the United States receive Social Security benefits. You may also have investments, an individual retirement account (IRA), or even a side hustle that you plan to continue in retirement to supplement your 401(k) savings.
The Western & Southern survey found that 90% of Baby Boomers and 71% of Gen X expect to rely on Social Security as their primary retirement income, whereas only about half of Millennials and Gen Z (55% and 51%, respectively) do.
5 Ways to Boost Retirement Savings
If you're in your 60s and your 401(k) isn’t where you want it to be, here's how to boost your 401(k) savings in the last few years before you retire.
1. Make Catch-Up Contributions
In 2025, the annual limit for 401(k) contributions for many people is $23,500. If you’re in your early 60s, though, you can put away even more. If you are age 60 to 63, you can make additional
catch-up contributions
of $11,250, for a total of $34,750. If you are age 64 or older, your catch-up contribution level is $7,500 for a total of $31,000 in 2025.
2. Use Workplace Benefits
Alexa Kane, a certified financial planner at Pearl Planning, recommends that anyone approaching retirement get as much as they can out of their workplace retirement benefits.
“If your employer offers
a match on retirement contributions
, contribute enough to get the full match,” she said, even if you’ve never maxed out your employer match before.
Kane also suggested automating savings to take the guesswork out of retirement contributions.
“Many retirement plans can be set up to automatically increase contributions by a percentage annually,” she said.
3. Reallocate Assets
In general, investors tend to hold more stocks in their 401(k)s when they are younger, taking on more risk in exchange for more growth. It’s common to gradually shift to a more conservative balance of stocks, bonds, and other assets as you near retirement. If your 401(k) is invested in a
target-date fund
, then this shift happens automatically.
If you’re in your 60s but feel like you aren’t on track with your savings, don’t immediately shift everything to conservative assets. Prioritizing growth for a few more years may help your 401(k) increase significantly in this decade. As you get closer to retirement, a gradual shift toward bonds and away from stocks will help protect your assets.
Tip
A financial planner can assess
what asset allocation is best
for you and advise you on when that allocation needs to change.
4. Consider Downsizing Now
If you are part of the 51% who plan to downsize in retirement,
consider downsizing
your living situation now instead.
Downsizing before you retire can significantly decrease your living expenses by reducing costs such as:
Property taxes
Home maintenance and repair
Homeowners insurance
Utility bills
If you are
strategic about where you move
, you can even prioritize things like access to public transportation, which can further reduce your living expenses by allowing you to drive less or own fewer cars.
Decreasing your living expenses can allow you to put more into
tax-advantaged
retirement accounts now, giving the money time to grow. This can be especially helpful if you are trying to max out your catch-up contributions in your early 60s, when you can put even more into your 401(k)
pretax
.
5. Work With an Advisor
Working with a financial advisor as you approach retirement can help you figure out not just how much money to save, but also what kind of retirement you want and how you can make that happen.
“There are many pictures of retirement,” Kane said. “And with any retirement plan, we say, ‘You can do anything, but not everything.’ There are pros and cons for every decision.”
Working with an advisor can help you think through your options and what tradeoffs you might have to make for certain choices. For example,
many retirees like the idea of living abroad
to get access to a lower cost of living, including cheaper healthcare. But the choice isn’t just between a more expensive life in one country and a more affordable life in another.
“A large international move requires careful planning and an understanding of associated laws and regulations,” Kane said. “You are still required to file U.S. taxes while living abroad. You also need to understand the
Foreign Earned Income Exclusion (FEIE)
and the
Foreign Tax Credit (FTC)
.”
A financial advisor can walk you through all these considerations and help you decide what kind of retirement makes sense based on your resources and priorities.
Article Sources
Investopedia requires writers to use primary sources to support their work. These include white papers, government data, original reporting, and interviews with industry experts. We also reference original research from other reputable publishers where appropriate. You can learn more about the standards we follow in producing accurate, unbiased content in our
editorial policy.

.”

Home in Retirement: More Freedom, New Choices
.” Page 9.

U.S. Citizens and Resident Aliens Abroad
."

Savings Accounts
Learn all there is to know about savings accounts from regular passbook to high yield to HSAs. Discover where to get the best interest rates, how they are taxed, and how a savings club works.
Savings Accounts
Best High-Yield Savings Account Rates for January 2026: Earn 5.00% APY
While You Still Can
Besides a Savings Account, Where Is the Safest Place To Keep My Money?
Understanding Savings Account Interest and the Power of Compounding
What Is a High-Yield Savings Account?
How to Open a High-Yield Savings Account
Frequently Asked Questions
What makes a savings account a high-yield account?
A savings account is considered high-yield if it pays more than a financial institution’s regular demand deposit or passbook savings accounts.  High yield savings accounts are typically money market savings accounts that are limited to six withdrawal transactions per month.
Learn More:
What Is a High-Yield Savings Account?
Are savings accounts subject to income tax?
Interest earned on savings accounts is reported to the IRS by commercial banks and other financial institutions and therefore is subject to federal income tax as regular income. Interest is reported on Form 1099 to bank customers, typically in January each year for the previous tax year.
Learn More:
How Is a Savings Account Taxed?
How do savings accounts differ from a Roth IRA?
Both savings accounts and Roth IRAs are funded with after-tax dollars by individual investors. However, unlike savings accounts, any capital appreciation earned with a Roth IRA is not subject to federal income tax. Growth in savings accounts, in the form of interest, is subject to taxation.
Learn More:
Savings Account vs. Roth IRA: What’s the Difference?
How is interest calculated on a savings account?
Simple interest for a savings account is calculated by multiplying the account balance by the stated interest rate and then multiplying by the time period the money is in the account. Interest = Principal amount X Interest Rate X Time Period.
Learn More:
How Interest Rates Work on Savings Accounts
How is a savings account different from a checking account?
A savings account is different from a checking account in that it is meant for accumulation of funds and earning interest rather than being a transaction account accessible with checks and debit cards. Savings accounts can be freely accessed by the account holder through deposits and withdrawals on demand and generally pay higher interest than checking accounts but are not designed for payment transactions.
Learn More:
The Difference Between Term Deposit vs. Demand Deposit
Key Terms
Savings Account
Deposit Interest Rate
Sweep Account
Passbook Loan
Linked Savings Account
Joint Account
Savings Account
A savings account is a deposit account held at a bank or other financial institution that pays interest on the balance held in the account. Interest rates are typically modest but these accounts provide safety for emergency funds and savings needed for long-term needs.
Learn More
Deposit Interest Rate
The deposit interest rate is the rate paid by banks and other financial institutions to deposit account customers in exchange for the use of their deposits to make loans. Deposit accounts include passbook savings, high-yield savings accounts, and certificates of deposit accounts.
Learn More
Sweep Account
A sweep account is a specialized account that is often attached to a brokerage account to automatically transfer or sweep cash funds into a low-risk, higher interest-earning investment such as a money market fund at the close of each business day.
Learn More
Passbook Loan
A passbook loan is a loan made to a savings account owner or depositor by the bank holding the funds. The savings account balances serve as collateral for the personal loan, which is also called a pledged asset loan.
Learn More
Linked Savings Account
A linked savings account is a deposit account connected to another account such as a checking or brokerage account. Linked savings accounts are usually held by the same financial institution as the customer's other accounts, facilitating efficient and timely transfer of funds between accounts.
Learn More
Joint Account
A joint account is a type of deposit account that is held by two or more people, often spouses. Joint accounts are generally checking or savings accounts where both parties can make account transactions like deposits and withdrawals individually.
Learn More

Investing
Investing differs from trading in that investing is for the long-term, usually years or decades. Investing is one of the key strategies to building long-term wealth and financial security.
A Beginner’s Guide to Investing
Investing: An Introduction
Understanding Stock Fundamentals: Key Metrics and Analysis
How To Start Investing in Stocks in 2025 and Beyond
Lower Trading Costs: Prevent Fees From Eating Investment Profits
4 Basic Things to Know About Bonds
Frequently Asked Questions
Can I start investing with $1000?
Yes, many
brokerages
have no minimum account size and will offer zero-commission trading, allowing you to begin investing with even very small amounts. In fact, now with many brokers offering fractional shares, you can invest in stocks even if their share price is over $1000.
Learn More:
How to Invest $1,000
How do I invest in stocks?
While there are many ways to invest in stocks, one of the easiest and best ways for beginning investors to do so is to open up a retirement account with a discount broker. These accounts have tax advantages when saving for retirement and many different brokers have ones that cost little or even nothing to have.
Learn More:
Best Investment Accounts for Young Investors
How can I invest with no money?
While you can’t invest with zero money, you can invest with very little. Many stock brokers offer accounts with no minimum balance and no trading commissions so almost any amount you add to your account can be used to invest.
Learn More:
How to Invest When You're Broke
Why should I invest?
You should invest because investing allows your savings to go farther than they otherwise would. Simply holding your savings as cash means it will just sit and be slowly diluted by inflation, whereas even in the safest investments it will earn some money for you, building on itself.
Learn More:
Why Should I Consider Investing?
When should I start investing?
As soon as you can afford to. Because investment returns compound, that is, the money you earn from investing then earns money, the sooner you begin investing, the more time you give for this process to work.
Learn More:
5 Advantages of Investing in Your 20s
What time does the stock market open and close?
In the U.S. stock markets major exchanges such as the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and Nasdaq are open from 9:30 .a.m to 4.p.m Eastern Time. However, this varies around the world depending on what exchange you’re looking at and whether that day is a holiday.
Learn More:
Stock Market Opening Times Around the World
Key Terms
Bond
Bond Yield
Technical Analysis
Sector Breakdown
Short-Term Investments
Investment Banker
Wall Street
Bond
A bond is an investment representing part or all of a loan to a person, government, or other entity. Bonds are issued at a set par value, usually $1000 or $100, and their prices fluctuates based on interest rates and perceived credit-worthiness of the borrower.
Learn More
Bond Yield
A bond’s yield is the investment return that an investor will gain from a bond, usually expressed as a percentage. This is the percent of the bond’s price that each set interest payment will be. Yields go up as a bond’s price goes down and vice versa because they are a percent of the bond’s value, therefore the higher the bond’s price, the lower a percentage of that value a set interest payment will be.
Learn More
Technical Analysis
Technical analysis is a form of stock analysis that involves looking at the price movements of stocks over time in order to predict where they will go. It attempts to find patterns in stock movements based on statistical trends such as the moving average of a stock or its trading volume. This contrasts with fundamental analysis which looks at the financial values of the business that issued the stock and economic conditions affecting the market and that business in order to assess where a stock’s price will go.
Learn More
Sector Breakdown
A sector breakdown is a way to look at a portfolio by organizing it by which sector of the economy each stock is in. This allows an investor to, depending on their investing strategy, avoid stocks from companies in sectors they don’t believe to have strong prospects, focus on stocks from sectors they believe are in a good position for growth, or ensure their portfolio is diversified.
Learn More
Short-Term Investments
Short term investments are investments that are designed to be held for a year or less or investments a company intends to sell within 12 months. They are also known as “marketable securities” or “temporary investments,” and can be easily sold for cash.
Learn More
Investment Banker
An investment banker works for a bank that deals mostly with raising capital for large institutions such as governments and corporations. They also deal with corporate restructuring as well as corporate mergers & acquisition (M&A).
Learn More
Wall Street
Wall Street is a street in New York City which, due to having been a historical center of the U.S. financial industry, is used as a term to refer to that industry as a whole. It is often contrasted to Main Street, which is used as a term to represent the broader economy outside the financial industry, especially small businesses.
Learn More
Boost Dividends Quickly With This Simple Strategy To Triple Your 3% Yield

Our Mission
Investopedia was founded in 1999 with the mission of helping people improve their financial outcomes. Our readers come to us from all over the world and from all walks of life. Some are learning about money and investing for the first time, while others are experienced investors, business owners, professionals, financial advisors, and executives looking to improve their knowledge and skills. No matter who you are, we are here to help.
Inclusive Content
Financial education needs to serve readers of all backgrounds. We aspire for our content, staff, contributors, and partner organizations to further the financial empowerment of those from all ethnicities, genders, generations, sexual orientations, abilities, and socioeconomic backgrounds, particularly those who may be disadvantaged.

Upgrading Your Vessel? Why a Resume of Experience Matters for Yacht Insurance
December 23, 2025								    In
Yacht Insurance
When you are looking to insure pleasure use yachts, the process can sometimes feel complicated. However, one of the most critical factors insurance companies look at isn’t just the boat itself—it’s you. Specifically, underwriters want to understand your history and overall experience as an owner.
In the world of yachting, experience is everything. This is especially true when you decide to purchase a vessel that is significantly different from ones you have owned before. For example, if your yacht owner’s history consists of vessels under 60 feet and you are now buying a 75-foot vessel, this “jump in length” is significant. It might require hiring a full-time captain to navigate the yacht.
Perhaps you are moving from twin-engine fishing boats to a sportfish with quads. This increase in power may cause concern for underwriters, potentially leading to a higher deductible or a “Named Operator Warranty” on the
yacht insurance policy
.
In these scenarios, carriers often require a detailed resume of your experience, including any loss/claim history, before providing an insurance quote. But why is this such a significant factor? Let’s dive in.
Request a Quote for Yacht Insurance
Understanding the “Jump” in Length and Power
For any yacht, the size and the power of its engines can significantly affect both its performance and the boating safety of its operation. The length overall of the yacht and the number of engines it has influence several important aspects.
1. Safety and Stability
A larger yacht usually requires advanced handling techniques because it is less maneuverable than a smaller boat. Similarly, multiple engines provide more power but introduce different handling characteristics, especially in rough waters.
2. Performance Expectations
Larger yachts with more powerful engines travel faster and cover greater distances. However, this comes with increased risk. A jump in length or power changes how the vessel behaves, and without proper experience, a yachter may struggle to control it within their navigation limits.
3. Wear and Tear
Larger yachts undergo greater stresses, which affect durability. Marine insurance providers need to understand this to evaluate risks accurately and adjust premiums or coverage options.
4. Operational Complexity
Managing a yacht
with increased length or multiple engines is far more complex than handling a smaller, single-engine yacht. The operation of additional engines requires a greater understanding of engine synchronization and fuel management, especially in an emergency.
Why Insurance Carriers Need a Resume of Experience Upfront
Providing a boating resume isn’t just paperwork; it’s about securing the right insurance protection for your specific needs.
Comprehensive Risk Assessment
A yacht’s size and power are directly tied to the risks an insurer needs to account for. The larger and more powerful the yacht, the higher the potential for property damage or bodily injury in an accident. By providing a resume upfront, insurance carriers can assess the operator’s experience with the yacht’s specifications to determine if they can handle the associated risks. This proactive risk management approach enables a thorough evaluation from the outset.
Enhanced Accuracy and Efficiency
Submitting a resume upfront ensures that all relevant details about the yacht owner’s experience are available early in the process. This minimizes the risk of discrepancies and provides consistent information. It also streamlines the decision-making process regarding insurance solutions, leading to faster processing times and quicker application approval.
Handling and Maintenance Knowledge
Handling a larger yacht with multiple engines requires specific skills. Whether it’s docking, navigating tight spots, or dealing with rough waters, these skills need to be built up over time. Insurance companies want to ensure that the yacht operator has experience with these nuances. A resume of experience that demonstrates a history of safe operation helps reassure insurers that the yacht is in capable hands.
Moreover,
regular maintenance of larger yachts
is crucial. Insurance carriers want to know that the yacht owner is proactive about maintaining the yacht properly, as this significantly affects the risk of mechanical failure or accidents.
Customized Coverage
With larger yachts or those with more complex systems, a generic policy—or relying on standard homeowners endorsements—will not provide the necessary coverage. A resume of experience helps insurers craft a policy that offers the right
yacht insurance coverage
.
When we look at your experience, we can better structure the policy to address:
Hull Coverage:
Protection for physical damage to your vessel
Agreed Value vs. Actual Cash Value:
Determining whether your policy covers the agreed value (the insured amount decided at the start) or the actual cash value (which factors in depreciation)
Liability Coverage:
Essential protection and indemnity (P&I) for third-party liabilities, including bodily injury and property damage
Medical Payments:
Coverage for necessary medical expenses for you or your passengers
Uninsured Boater:
Protection if you are hit by someone who lacks proper coverage
Personal Property and Personal Effects:
Protecting your belongings on board, separate from the vessel itself
Wreck Removal:
Covering the cost to remove your vessel if it sinks or blocks a waterway
Jones Act:
Coverage for crew members
if you employ a captain or crew
Lay-up:
Defining periods when the boat is out of commission, which can affect premiums
Understanding these coverage options helps you answer the question, “What kind of insurance do you need for a yacht?” versus a smaller boat.
Request a Quote for Yacht Insurance
Yachtsman Education and Experience
Yachtsman education, certifications such as Merchant Marine, Captains License, USCG Auxiliary, or United States Power Squadron courses, and hands-on experience play a vital role in how an insurer assesses risk. Underwriters prefer operators with a proven track record. By detailing your certifications and boating courses, you can improve your chances of receiving comprehensive insurance solutions at the most competitive terms and premiums.
Demonstrating a commitment to boating safety and continuous learning—such as staying up to date on navigation limits and new technologies—builds trust. This transparency can positively influence the terms of your policy, offering you greater peace of mind.
Building Trust and Credibility
Providing a resume upfront demonstrates transparency and a willingness to share comprehensive information. This builds trust with the underwriters and shows that the yacht owner is serious about the application process. It reassures insurance carriers that the owner is committed to safe and knowledgeable yachting practices, which can positively influence the terms and conditions of the insurance policy.
Additional Considerations for Yacht Owners
The Role of Technology in Modern Yachting
Modern yachts are equipped with advanced technology that can enhance safety and performance, but also add to the complexity of operation. A detailed resume of experience should highlight any training or experience the yacht owner has with these technologies. This can further reassure insurance carriers that the owner is well-prepared to handle the sophisticated systems onboard.
Environmental Considerations
Larger yachts and those with multiple engines can have a greater environmental impact. Responsible yacht ownership includes understanding and mitigating this impact. Demonstrating a commitment to environmental stewardship can be a positive factor when seeking insurance coverage.
The Importance of Continuous Learning
The world of yachting is constantly evolving. Continuous learning is essential for staying up to date and ensuring safe, responsible yacht operation. Including a history of continuous learning on your resume of experience can demonstrate to insurers that you are committed to maintaining and enhancing your skills over time.
The Role of Professional Networks
Being part of professional yachting networks or associations can provide yacht owners with valuable support and resources. These networks often offer access to training, industry news, and best practices. They can also provide a platform for sharing experiences and learning from other yacht owners. Mentioning your involvement in professional networks or associations on your resume can further bolster your credibility with insurance carriers.
Securing Your Investment and Peace of Mind
A jump in size and/or number of engines in some instances can impact your insurability. Insurance carriers rely on a detailed resume of experience to assess whether the yacht is being operated by an insured or by a captain accustomed to navigating similar vessels. Additionally, the cost of ownership and maintenance of the yacht has become more complex and more expensive.
Whether you are purchasing a new yacht with significant differences in size and engine capacity from your prior yachting experience, providing a comprehensive resume of your experience upfront is essential.
Ensuring that your resume includes detailed information about your yachting history, education, certifications, and relevant occupational skills can significantly enhance your chances of obtaining the best possible boat insurance or
yacht insurance coverage
. This proactive approach not only protects your investment against partial losses or replacement costs but also contributes to a safer, more enjoyable yachting experience.
The resume of experience is not just a formality but a crucial document that reflects your capability and commitment as a yacht owner. It serves as a testament to your skills, knowledge, and dedication to safe yachting practices. By providing a detailed, comprehensive resume of your experience upfront, you can build confidence with insurance carriers, ensuring you receive the liability insurance and physical damage coverage you need to protect your valuable asset and enjoy the full benefits of yacht ownership.
FAQs About Yacht Insurance
What Factors Affect the Cost of Yacht Insurance?
Several factors influence your premium, including the vessel’s value, size, age, cruising area (navigation limits), your boating resume, and the deductible you choose.
What is a Normal Deductible?
A deductible is the amount you pay out of pocket before insurance covers the rest. For yachts, this is typically a percentage of the insured value (often 1% to 2%). An increased Named Storm Deductible is also applicable to most yacht policies. Note that in the event of a total loss, the deductible application may vary based on your specific policy terms.
Do I Need Yacht Insurance for International Waters?
Standard boat insurance usually has specific territorial limits. If you plan to travel internationally, you must inform your broker to ensure your yacht insurance coverage extends to those regions.
What Are the Exclusions from Yacht Insurance Policies?
Standard exclusions include wear and tear, gradual deterioration, osmosis, and damage caused by lack of maintenance. Indemnity is generally intended for sudden, accidental losses, not for maintenance issues.
Ready to upgrade your vessel? Contact a W3 Marine Insurance Advisor today to secure coverage for your new yacht.

10 Most Common Boat Insurance Claims
August 26, 2022								    In
Boat Insurance
Boat Ownership
Florida Boating
For Florida boat owners, being out on the water is one of life’s true pleasures.
But sometimes things don’t go as planned. Some incidents happen often enough to give all boat owners reason to pause and wonder:
does my boat have insurance
?
If you’re in the market to buy a boat, marine insurance is
one of the most important things to consider
during that process.
While boat insurance isn’t required in Florida, it’s a sound strategy to purchase a policy. No one can predict what will happen out on the water, and even the most careful captain can encounter difficulties on the waterways. Marine insurance exists to bail out boat owners during what could otherwise be
a financial disaster or the loss of your boat
.
What’s more, the coverage offers peace of mind. Every time you head out on the water, know that you’re protected by the invisible but vital coverage of Florida boat insurance.
Why do I need boat insurance?
Accidents happen.
Boats collide. They sink. They hit docks, break their tethers during storms, experience a crushed t-top when the tree they’re parked underneath drops a huge branch. The list is long, and a Florida marine insurance advisor will have plenty of stories to share that prove coverage is truly imperative.
Boat collision insurance is a popular coverage option, because the reality of a craft crashing into yours (or the other way around) is a possible one. Stories about such instances are widespread. If you collide with another boat and your passengers or the other boat’s passengers are injured, you could be sued. You could be taken to court for
medical expenses
and more. The correct marine insurance coverage will mitigate the damage.
Homeowners insurance isn’t enough.
When you’re out on the water, you’re going to need the
specialized coverage
that only a solid marine insurance policy provides. And before you worry about sticker shock, it’s likely less expensive than you might think. Partner with a Florida marine insurance advisor who has access to A-rated markets and understands how to combine coverages into an entire package, and you can find comprehensive coverage without breaking the bank.
What does boat insurance cover?
As with most insurance coverage options, you can make your boat policy an
a la carte
combo of what is important to you as a boat owner. You’ll have different types of insurance to choose from. Partnering with a seasoned marine insurance advisor will take much of the work off your plate.
Different types of boating insurance include:
Collision
When two crafts collide, the results can be disastrous. There can be a loss of life, a loss of property, or, at the very least, the need for repairs on the craft. Purchase boat collision insurance (hull and liability coverage) to safeguard yourself against these costs. And remember: It’s not enough to say that you’ll just be ‘extra careful’ out there on the water. A collision takes two captains to occur – and that other boat driver may not be as experienced or careful as you are. They also may not carry insurance, leaving the financial burden on you.
Comprehensive
Comprehensive insurance (included in hull coverage)on your boat includes vandalism and theft. When you leave that expensive navigation equipment or personal items on board you’re leaving yourself open to possible theft. In fact, your entire boat could be taken or damaged through vandalism – intentional or natural. Comprehensive coverage provides the money needed to restore the boat to shipshape condition.
Liability
Don’t skip this coverage; if you’re found liable for loss of property or physical damage to another person, a claim against you for liability can be in the millions. This will even cover your defense costs if that becomes necessary.
The 10 Most Common Boat Insurance Claims
We’ve compiled some common Florida boat insurance claims in order to show you how beneficial it continues to be for boat owners.
1. Hurricanes
Floridians live with the threat of these mega storms on a regular basis. Some common insurance claims having to do with hurricane damage include boats improperly secured on lifts and vessels that are damaged by storm debris.  Most marine policies have an increased deductible for Named (or numbered) Storms.
2. Windy Weather
It doesn’t take the wrath of a hurricane to damage a boat by weather. Tornados can wreak havoc on a boat, and a windstorm strong enough to turn objects into projectiles can severely damage a boat.
3. Sinking (as the result of a covered loss)
Recovering a boat that has sunk underneath the water can be majorly expensive; that is, unless you carry boat insurance that covers this unfortunate event.
4. Hitting Underwater Objects
Even the best viewfinder doesn’t always function perfectly. Hit an underwater object, and the damage to your hull may render your craft useless. What’s more, that underwater object can result in the sinking of your boat.
5. Fire and Explosion
A fire or explosion can completely total your boat. Imagine not having insurance in this situation; you would have no recompense and would have to count your vessel as a complete loss.
6. Collision With Another Boat
This is a very real possibility. It’s so important to carry boat collision coverage (hull and liability coverage) for legal and financial purposes alike. An accident in which both boat owners carry insurance is going to be much less devastating on the pocketbook than one in which neither (or just one) has it. Remember: a court can order you to pay damages to another party, even if you cannot afford to do so. Cover yourself in case this does happen, and you safeguard not only your current bank account, but your future earnings as well.
7. Grounding
Running a boat aground is unfortunately common; thanks to the ever-changing levels of tides, it’s easy to misjudge or forget that certain parts of the waterways are not deep enough. Rescuing and repairing a boat that has run aground requires some specialized assistance – and that can be expensive if paying out-of-pocket.
8. Equipment Theft
Even the most careful captain (and your crew) can forget to remove equipment from a boat. If you regularly stow expensive items aboard, protect the collection by insuring it.
9. Boat Theft
Should your boat be stolen, Florida boat insurance can make the sting a little less severe. You’ll be able to purchase a new vessel to continue your exploration of the Sunshine State waterways. Otherwise, you’ll be left with a boat lift or trailer that stands empty until you can save enough money to purchase a new vessel.
10. Lightning
This is covered by marine insurance when you purchase hull coverage.  It’s a huge risk factor for Florida boats and replacing your navigational equipment can be quite costly.
Contact W3 Insurance for a quote
Hopefully, this article inspires you to do the right thing for yourself and your passengers: purchase a marine insurance policy. It’s not a luxury; it’s protection. W3 is here to help so that you select the coverage that’s right for you and your boat.
Contact W3 today for a quote
.

How to Choose the Best Charter Boat Insurance for Your Needs
July 23, 2025								    In
Charter Insurance
Owning and operating a charter boat is more than just a business; it’s about creating memories, whether through fishing trips, sightseeing, or special events. But like any business, charter operations come with risks. That’s where
charter boat insurance
steps in, offering the protection you need to focus on your business confidently.
This guide will explain everything you need to know about charter boat insurance, from coverage options to key benefits, ensuring you make informed decisions for your charter business.
What Is Charter Boat Insurance?
Charter boat insurance
is a specialized type of marine insurance designed to protect charter boat owners and operators from risks specific to their operations. These policies provide coverage for vessels used for hire, ensuring you’re protected against liabilities, property damage, and unforeseen accidents.
Whether you’re running fishing charters, harbor sightseeing tours, or private parties on the water, having the right insurance is not just recommended but vital for compliance and peace of mind.
Request a Quote
Understanding Charter Boat Classifications and Their Impact on Insurance
Vessels Carrying 6 or Fewer Passengers
These vessels are classified as Uninspected Passenger Vessels (UPVs) and have fewer regulatory requirements:
Captain Requirements:
The captain must hold a valid U.S. Coast Guard (USCG)-issued Merchant Mariner Credential (MMC) and be enrolled in a drug and alcohol testing program.
Safety Equipment:
The vessel must carry appropriate
safety equipment
, including life jackets and fire extinguishers.
Operational Limitations:
Generally restricted to nearshore waters; a permit may be necessary for Federal waters.
Vessels Carrying 12 or More Passengers
These vessels are classified as Small Passenger Vessels and must adhere to stricter regulations:
Certificate of Inspection (COI):
A valid COI issued by the USCG is required.
Captain and Crew Requirements:
The captain and crew must hold appropriate USCG licenses and be enrolled in a drug and alcohol testing program.
Safety Equipment:
The vessel must be equipped with Type I personal flotation devices for all persons aboard.
Operational Limitations:
These vessels can operate in both nearshore and offshore waters, provided they comply with all safety and operational regulations.
Compliance and Penalties
Failure to comply with USCG regulations can result in significant penalties:
Civil Penalties:
Fines up to $5,996 for not having a valid COI when carrying more than six passengers for hire.
Captain of the Port Orders:
Violating a Captain of the Port Order can lead to civil penalties of up to $117,608 per day of violation.
Key Types of Charter Boat Insurance Coverage
Charter boat insurance goes beyond standard marine policies to address specific risks unique to commercial operations. Here are the most common
types of coverage
to consider for your insurance needs.
Liability Coverage:
This provides
protection from claims
involving bodily injury or property damage that occur during charter operations. This includes legal liability to passengers and third parties.
Hull and Machinery Coverage:
This protects against physical damage to your vessel, including the costs of repairs or replacement. Offering “agreed value” policies ensures reimbursement based on the insured value of the boat.
Medical Payments:
This covers medical expenses for injuries sustained by crew members or passengers.
Pollution Liability:
This is essential coverage for environmental cleanup and damages resulting from your boat leaking fuel or oil into the water.
Personal Property Coverage:
This protects personal belongings aboard.
Uninsured Boater Coverage:
This coverage provides bodily injury protection in the event of an accident involving an uninsured boater or underinsured boater.
Additional Optional Coverages:
Coverage for fishing equipment and other special items
Crew coverage under the
Jones Act
Charter Insurance vs. Pleasure-Use Boat Insurance
Understanding the distinctions between charter insurance and pleasure-use boat insurance is crucial for ensuring proper coverage tailored to your vessel’s intended purpose.
Intended Use: Pleasure vs. Commercial
Pleasure Use Policy:
Covers private, non-commercial activities; excludes commercial activities.
Charter Policy:
Designed for vessels used for hire; often required if operating under a USCG credential.
Liability Coverage
Pleasure:
Limited to personal use; doesn’t cover injuries to paying passengers.
Charter:
Covers bodily injury and legal liability to charter passengers; may include Jones Act coverage for captain/crew.
Passenger Risk
Pleasure:
Covers guests, not passengers for hire.
Charter:
Covers paying clients; includes charter passenger liability and possibly crew coverage.
Compliance and Endorsements
Charter Policies:
Require proof of Coast Guard licensing, vessel inspections, commercial endorsements, and possible Jones Act coverage.
Pleasure Policies:
Void coverage if used for commercial purposes.
Cost
Charter Insurance:
More expensive due to increased risk; premiums depend on various factors like vessel size, number of passengers, cruising area, and charter type.
What Is a Bareboat Charter?
A bareboat charter is when you lease the vessel without crew, fuel, or provisions, and the charterer takes full responsibility for its operation.
Who’s in Charge?
Bareboat Charter:
The charterer is responsible for hiring their own captain and crew, assuming legal and operational control.
Crewed (For-Hire) Charter:
The vessel owner/operator supplies a licensed captain and crew.
Legal & Regulatory Differences
Feature
Bareboat Charter
Crewed/For-Hire Charter
Control of Vessel
Charterer (renter)
Vessel Owner
USCG Inspection
Not required (if under 12 passengers)
Vessel must be operated by a Master who holds an OUPV Merchant Mariner Credential and Coast Guard safety inspections may be required.
Captain Provided?
No (must be hired by charterer)
Yes (provided by vessel owner/operator)
Liability
On the charterer
On the vessel owner/operator
Passenger Limit*
A chartered vessel may NOT carry more than 12 passengers without a Certificate of Inspection (COI)
6 for UPVs (uninspected) vessels less than 100 GRT greater than 100 GRT can carry up to 12 passengers
Insurance Type Needed
Bareboat-specific charter policy
Commercial/charter boat insurance
*
Reference link:
https://wow.uscgaux.info/Uploads_wowII/P-DEPT/PaxForHire_trifold.pdf
Common Pitfall: Bareboat Charters
The USCG enforces strict regulations on charters that appear like bareboat charters but operate like crewed charters. Red flags include:
The owner picking the captain for the charterer.
Pre-stocked fuel, drinks, or supplies.
The crew was paid by the boat owner.
Passengers think they’re just renting a boat with a crew.
Insurance Differences
Bareboat Charter Insurance:
This needs to cover hull, liability, and passenger injury; stricter underwriting is required due to the liability shift.
Crewed Charter Insurance:
This type of insurance covers the vessel, passengers, captain, and crew under commercial marine insurance policies.
What Affects the Cost of Charter Boat Insurance?
The
cost of charter boat insurance
depends on various factors. Understanding these elements can help charter operators evaluate policies effectively.
Boat Value and Type:
Higher-value vessels or specialized watercraft (e.g., fishing boats) may carry higher premiums.
Operating Area:
Geographic location impacts risk assessments. Operating in calm, inland waters often costs less than in offshore environments.
Captain’s Experience:
More experienced and licensed captains may avoid a premium surcharge.
Coverage Options:
Policies with additional features, crew coverage or personal property protection, typically increase costs.
Deductibles:
Choosing a higher deductible can lower premium costs.
Safety Measures:
Boats equipped with
advanced safety technology
or maintained in accordance with USCG standards often qualify for discounts.
How to Choose the Right Policy for Your Charter Business
With countless insurance companies and marine underwriters offering specialized packages, finding the right coverage involves a step-by-step process.
1. Determine Your Insurance Needs
Understand what’s essential for your charter business, like liability limits, passenger capacity, and the type of vessel. Consider optional add-ons to strengthen protection for your specific risks.
2. Compare Charter Boat Insurance Quotes
At W3, we will seek quotes from reputable marine insurance carriers to compare costs with coverage.
3. Consult With a W3 Marine Insurance Advisor
A knowledgeable agent familiar with both commercial and marine insurance products can help you identify gaps in coverage and ensure compliance with federal and local regulations.
4. Review Exclusions in Policies
Ensure there are no hidden gaps (e.g., some policies exclude coverage during private events or if a captain doesn’t meet specific criteria).
5. Work With Specialists
Insurance agencies like WWW specialize in marine business insurance solutions, tailoring policies to fit unique operational requirements and risks.
Request a Quote
Why Charter Boat Insurance is Essential
Running a charter
boat business
comes with both rewards and risks. While you’re busy growing your business and delivering incredible experiences, you need comprehensive coverage for peace of mind. Charter boat insurance safeguards your finances, vessel, passengers, and crew from unforeseen hazards, ensuring your business can thrive without interruptions.
Whether you’re running full-time fishing charters or hosting sightseeing tours in Florida’s waters, having the right insurance coverage guarantees compliance with marine regulations and protects against financial liabilities.
Choosing the right insurance policy shouldn’t feel like navigating uncharted waters. At WWW, we offer customized solutions tailored to the charter boat industry.
Call us at (727) 522-7777 or
request a quote online
to ensure your charter operations are protected by the best in the business.
FAQs About Charter Boat Insurance
What type of insurance do you need to charter a boat?
You need a tailored policy that includes liability insurance, hull protection, passenger medical coverage, and optional endorsements, such as pollution liability. Speak with a marine insurance advisor for detailed policy advice.
How do I report a claim on my boat insurance policy?
To file a claim, contact your insurance company immediately with details about the incident (e.g., date, damages, and evidence). Many insurers also provide online portals to streamline reporting.
How much does insurance cost for a charter fishing boat?
Premiums will vary based on the type of charter risk, operational region, passenger & crew count, and claim experience. Contact us today to speak with a W3 Marine Insurance Advisor.

Everything You Need to Know to Own a Boat in Florida
August 12, 2022								    In
Boat Insurance
Boat Ownership
Florida Boating
The state of Florida is made up of close to 19% water. From the marshy Everglades to the tarpon-rich waters near Boca Grande, it’s a boater’s paradise. Join the ranks of those discovering the restorative nature of boat life.
Here is everything you need to know about owning a boat in Florida.
Basic Boat Safety Tips
The number one most important element to consider when purchasing a boat in Florida is the boating prowess of the owner. That’s right: before you consider engines, hulls, power poles, or any navigational equipment, be honest about your experience level and your commitment to the craft. Purchase a boat you are comfortable captaining. A vessel that is too large, or that demands more than your training level, may leave you sitting on the shore, uncertain. Research the different types of boats thoroughly and select one that you feel confident driving.
Having a high level of confidence regarding the craft you captain is the most basic of basic boat safety tips. The next ‘must have’ element for every boat owner is the
boat safety kit
, which should always remain aboard.
Just as a Florida homeowner is advised to keep a hurricane preparedness kit just in case, so too must the Florida boat owner have a selection of items that help in the event of an accident or loss of power.
Common safety kit items
Flashlight (and batteries)
– Should your vessel break down in the nighttime hours, you’ll be glad to have the illumination.
Emergency radio
– We’ve all been in situations without a phone charger when we really need it. The emergency radio is there even if your cell phone isn’t – a link between you and those on shore.
Mirror for signaling and whistle for alerting
– Hold a mirror up to the sun, and you can deflect that sunlight far away. Even if your electronic equipment fails, that signal can be seen for miles. A whistle is a simple object that can help to alert others of your presence and need for help.
Properly prepared first aid kit
– There are many different types of first aid kits. Compile your own or purchase a kit specifically packed for Florida boaters. Inside, you’ll find the usual bandages, ointments, etc. We recommend adding sunscreen to the mix (that Florida sun can be brutal, and if you’re stranded, you’ll be glad to have it).
Fire extinguisher and garbage bags
– The need for the fire extinguisher is apparent, but garbage bags? – Yes, they are a worthy addition to the Florida boater safety kit. Use garbage bags as ponchos if it rains or to help conserve heat in cold weather.
Life jackets
– There needs to be one
life jacket
for every person aboard, regardless of age, even if they are expert swimmers. They should be approved by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Duct tape, buckets, and ropes
– Duct tape might not fix everything, but it can plug a small leak and give you enough time to get your craft back to shore. A simple bucket plays an important role if you need to bail out. And ropes are a must on any craft, at least to tie up to docks and rescue an overboard passenger.
Now that you have the items necessary to make up a Florida boat safety kit, it’s time to educate yourself regarding active, in-the-moment boat safety practices. Hopefully, if you follow the guidance of your boating safety class, you will never need the safety kit at all.
Recommended Boating Safety Courses
Did you know that you are
required to take a boat safety course
? If you are operating a motorized boat of more than 10 horsepower and were born during or after 1988, you are required to do so – an important part of keeping our waterways safe.
Look for a course that is Florida-approved; different options exist, including online selections. We suggest this one from
Boat Ed
. You can also peruse the list curated by the
Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission
for a solid list of options.
After you’ve aced your Florida boating safety course, make sure you know what to do if your boat breaks down or is involved in an accident. Knowledge gives peace of mind–that’s why we’ve compiled this boating accident and breakdown guide for a quick snapshot regarding what to do if your Florida boat runs into trouble.
Boating Accident and Breakdown Guide
Should a boating accident or breakdown occur, do an immediate check of everyone aboard for injury and to see what medical attention, if any, is needed. Break out the Florida boat first aid kit and tend to any wounds. Then, call for help using your cell phone or the emergency radio aboard.
What to do when involved in a boating accident
Document
the moment as much as possible. In the frenzy of stress that always accompanies a boating accident, major details can be lost. Take pictures of any damage and, instead of writing things down, you can dictate what happened and save the recording in your phone.
Determine if the U.S. Coast Guard should be notified
.
Call your marine insurance agent
and let them know what has happened. Hopefully, you’ve opted for comprehensive insurance protection that has you, your passengers, and your beloved boat covered.
What to do in the event of a breakdown
Try to move your craft out of the way
, if possible, if you are on a heavily-traveled waterway. This could save your boat from a collision.
Call the nearest harbor master,
or break out the emergency radio and call for help. Different tow services exist to help boaters who are stranded, or the Coast Guard may come to your aid if appropriate.
Where to store your boat
It’s important to know what to do
on
the water, but how are you protecting your boat when you’re
not
exploring the Florida waterways? There are several options available to you.
Storing your boat in Florida is quite easy. You could leave it outside your residence–keeping the vessel nearby and avoiding marina fees There are some drawbacks to this commonsense approach, however.
Exposing your craft to the elements
is a surefire way for it to deteriorate more quickly. A pervasive example of this is upholstery. Even the most watertight boat cushions are going to eventually disintegrate, and the more you expose a boat to the elements, the quicker this will occur. You could keep your boat in the garage, of course, but the vessel will take up most of that valuable storage and parking space.
Lift storage
Perhaps you have a lift outside your home, ready for your boat to be perched and lowered. This is a solid Florida boat storage selection, but make sure that if a hurricane or tropical storm looms, you’ve taken the necessary precautions to keep that on-site boat secured.
Marina storage
Storage at a marina is another viable way to keep your boat safe and at the ready for future voyages. Often, marinas will offer security details–but you should still never keep expensive equipment aboard when storing your boat.
For those who don’t live on the water, or who don’t want to keep a boat on their property, a marina can be a wonderful choice. Before you select one, make sure to thoroughly understand their
rules and regulations
, especially how easy (or difficult) it will be to access your craft whenever you’d like.
Dry stack storage
In dry stacking, boats are placed on racks, often indoors and away from the elements. To retrieve your boat, you’ll need to call the storage facility ahead of time and have it lowered and prepared to move safely to your trailer via forklift. This storage option is attractive to those who boat rarely or don’t reside in Florida permanently.
Boatyard storage
Boatyard storage is a hybrid Florida boat storage option that combines dry stack storage with near-marina storage. In this case, the stacked boats are kept outside but not necessarily on the water. This is less expensive than marina storage and keeps you relatively close to an embarkation point. You’ll need to follow the same call-ahead process you’d use when dry docking.
No matter which Florida boat storage mode you select, resist the impulse to keep the vessel in the water for an extended period of time. Salt water is highly corrosive to boats and, for those not in salt water, weather damage can be catastrophic. At the very least, lift the boat out of the water and remove any electronic equipment and valuables after every excursion.
Importance of marine insurance
Florida marine insurance is so absolutely vital. When it comes to everything you need to know to own a boat in this beautiful state, understanding marine insurance ranks near the top of requirements for safe boating.
Marine insurance is the ultimate protection for your vessel. Consider it a sort of ‘invisible life jacket’ you carry with you as you navigate the waterways. Before you ever load the fishing gear and cooler, stock the first aid kit, or chart that first Sunshine State boating excursion, you must protect yourself, your passengers, and your vessel from the unexpected. No one can predict the future–but marine insurance can safeguard you against many unexpected troubles.
Things to consider when purchasing Florida marine insurance
Insurance cost
depends on the type of vessel, the surrounding environment, the contents aboard, and how you’ll use the boat. You will want to consider physical damage coverage and liability while also considering optimal coverages available to you.
Call an experienced advisor
to compile a
personalized policy
, as it is easy to miss a vital part of insurance protection. A marine insurance advisor considers multiple elements before ever suggesting a policy.
If an accident were to occur
, would your passengers’ medical care be covered? Who is liable for those injury-related costs? Your marine insurance advisor can help answer these questions and propose solutions.
Prepare for the worst and hope for the best.
That’s what Florida marine insurance is there for– to protect you and your craft in a worst-case scenario, while allowing you to go on every voyage with the calm that comes from that protection.
Stay Protected with W3 Insurance
Florida marine insurance is the ultimate life jacket. Cover your vessel and those aboard, and set off to explore the Sunshine State’s famous waterways. Stay covered with help from W3 Marine Insurance–and bon voyage! Speak with an experienced marine insurance advisor and
request a quote today
.

What Is the Jones Act?
April 12, 2025								    In
Yacht Insurance
What Is the Jones Act? A Guide for Yacht Owners
The Jones Act
, formally known as the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, is one of the most critical pieces of legislation in U.S. maritime law. While you may have heard this term within shipping, boating, or insurance discussions, understanding its wide-reaching implications is essential, especially if you’re a yacht owner or maritime professional with captain/crew exposures.
Below, we explore key aspects of the Jones Act to help you understand your obligations, protect your crew, and ensure compliance with this federal law.
If you’re a
yacht owner
looking to ensure comprehensive protection for your vessel and crew, we invite you to contact our marine insurance advisors. They can provide a
tailored yacht insurance
quote with crew coverage, ensuring you have the proper protection.
What Is the Jones Act?
The Jones Act is a federal law designed to protect U.S.-flagged vessels, their operators, and their crews. It governs coastwise trade and establishes specific requirements for ships operating between U.S. ports or conducting domestic trade. It was enacted by the U.S. Congress to stimulate the shipping industry in the wake of World War I.
Here are some basic principles of the law:
U.S.-built ships must transport goods or passengers between U.S. ports.
Companies operating under the Jones Act must employ U.S. citizens or permanent residents.
The Act prioritizes the interests of the American Merchant Marine and national security in a global shipping industry.
For yacht owners, one of the most critical aspects of the Jones Act is its focus on safety and working conditions for maritime workers. Let’s take a closer look at how this legislation can impact your responsibilities as a yacht owner.
1. Captain/Crew Protections
The Jones Act provides workers with necessary legal rights, including your yacht’s captain and crew. If a crew member sustains injuries while working on your vessel, they have the right to file claims for compensation. These claims often include
damages for medical expenses
, lost wages, and even pain and suffering.
If your captain or crew members feel unsupported, their dissatisfaction could escalate into legal claims. Protecting your crew isn’t just about compliance—it’s about preserving harmony and professionalism aboard your vessel.
Key Tip:
Make sure your insurance policy provides comprehensive captain/crew coverage to meet these obligations.
2. Liability and Negligence
Under the Jones Act, yacht owners can be held responsible for injuries caused by negligence or unsafe conditions on board. This means it’s your responsibility to:
Ensure proper safety measures are in place.
Conduct routine inspections for potential hazards.
Maintain your vessel’s overall seaworthiness.
Failing to operate a safe and secure yacht puts your crew at risk and exposes you to expensive legal claims.
Insurance Tip:
Many yacht insurance policies offer liability protections to reduce financial risks from negligence claims. Speak to a marine insurance professional to ensure your yacht’s policy includes this crucial coverage.
3. Maintenance and Cure
One of the essential provisions of the Jones Act is the requirement to provide “maintenance and cure” for injured crew members.
Maintenance
covers the crew member’s daily living expenses while recovering.
Cure
pays for their medical treatment until they reach maximum medical improvement (MMI).
This obligation applies regardless of fault, so even if the crew member’s injury wasn’t caused by negligence, as a yacht owner, you’re still responsible. Coverage for maintenance and cure claims helps ensure your yacht operation remains financially sustainable in the event of crew injuries.
4. Obligation to Provide Captain/Crew Coverage
Providing comprehensive insurance coverage for your captain and crew isn’t optional—it’s a legal and moral obligation.
This coverage should include protection for:
Injury due to negligence
Claims about safety in the work environment
Claims for lost wages, pain and suffering, or disability
Maintenance and cure obligations
Third-party passenger liability, if applicable
By ensuring proper insurance coverage, you safeguard your crew’s well-being and protect your financial interests.
Proactive Measure:
Consult an experienced marine insurance provider to create a policy tailored to your yacht’s unique needs.
5. Jones Act Requirements for Vessels
While the Jones Act primarily applies to
commercial vessels
, its focus on crew protections and overall safety extends to yacht owners with captain and crew exposures.
Additionally, the law emphasizes adherence to coastwise laws, such as hiring U.S. citizens or permanent residents as crew members. Special cases like transporting goods or docking in Puerto Rico, Hawaii, Alaska, or along coastlines may invoke specific Jones Act rules.
Yacht owners must take these regulations seriously to avoid non-compliance.
6. Seaworthiness Requirement
The Jones Act includes an implied warranty of seaworthiness, meaning that as a yacht owner, you are obligated to ensure that your vessel is reasonably fit for its intended use. This includes keeping the vessel safe for the captain/crew to work on.
If a captain/crew member is injured due to the vessel’s unseaworthiness, they may have grounds to file a negligence claim for which the yacht owner would be liable. In some instances, a judgment could be placed against the vessel itself.
7. Economic and Security Implications
The Jones Act is a central piece of legislation for protecting the rights and safety of U.S. maritime workers, including your yacht’s captain/crew. The Act maintains a robust and regulated maritime workforce, thus supporting the domestic maritime industry overall. Ensuring compliance and understanding your responsibilities under the Jones Act helps you provide a safe and secure environment for your captain/crew while minimizing potential liabilities.
8. Consequences of Not Providing Coverage
Failing to meet your obligations as stipulated under the Jones Act can result in:
Costly lawsuits from crew members seeking compensation.
Personal liability, with significant out-of-pocket expenses.
Consequences that may financially jeopardize your vessel’s operation.
By understanding your responsibilities and securing robust insurance coverage, you can avoid these penalties while fostering trust and security among your crew.
Secure Your Vessel’s Future
Interested in learning more about how the Jones Act applies to your yacht? W3 Insurance’s team of marine insurance experts is here to help.
Contact us
today for a consultation and customized yacht insurance quotes that meet your needs.
This overview is intended for informational purposes only and should not be considered legal advice. For specific legal guidance, please consult a qualified attorney familiar with maritime law. Founded in 1925, WWW Insurance has a rich history of providing quality service and an unwavering commitment to its clients and community.
FAQs about the Jones Act
What Is the Jones Act in Simple Terms?
The Jones Act, also known as the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, sets requirements for U.S. vessels and protects maritime workers, enabling them to seek compensation for on-the-job injuries.
Who Benefits from the Jones Act?
The Act benefits U.S. maritime workers, including captains and crew members. It also supports national security by safeguarding domestic shipping and strengthening the U.S. merchant fleet.
Is the Jones Act Applicable in Puerto Rico?
Yes, the law applies to Puerto Rico, restricting non-U.S.-flagged ships or foreign-flag vessels from transporting goods between U.S. and Puerto Rican ports.
Can the Jones Act Be Waived?
A waiver of the Jones Act can be granted during national emergencies or times of war, but these waivers are temporary and subject to conditions set by Homeland Security. Requests for waivers of specific provisions of the Act are reviewed by the U.S. Maritime Administration (MARAD) on a case-by-case basis.
Why Is the Jones Act Controversial?
Critics argue that the Act increases shipping costs by requiring goods to be transported on U.S.-owned and operated vessels, limiting competition from foreign ships in the U.S. economy. However, supporters view it as vital for protecting national security and the U.S. maritime industry.

The Best Storage Options to Protect Your Boat
August 15, 2022								    In
Boat Ownership
Yacht Insurance
Protect your boat from the elements
Searching for the best boat storage options? Keep your vessel shipshape by shielding it from the elements and you’ll reap the longevity benefits that come with a well-maintained marine craft.
Unless you store your vessel indoors in a hurricane-safe storage facility, it’s often difficult to keep it completely safe from the elements.
There are different ways to achieve this aim, and it’s helpful to consider each one before making your ultimate boat storage selection. Reduce wear and tear on your boat by selecting the option that’s right for you.
First, let’s answer the obvious question: Why is it important to properly store your boat? In a perfect world, boats would be impervious to the effects of weather or corrosion. You could park your vessel in the driveway and never worry about a tree falling and damaging onboard contents; it would be just fine to tie up to a dock and keep that hull bobbing in the water indefinitely. This is a world where corrosion exists, unfortunately. The threat of potentially violent weather poses a threat as well. Therefore, it is important to have a plan for securing your boat accordingly. How you do that is up to you, but this guide can help you decide.
So what are your boat storage Florida options? You can store the boat either in-the-water or out, covered or wide open. But there are more options than you might think. What really wins the blue ribbon for ‘the best boat storage option’ depends on the type of boat and the storage options that are actually nearby.
The answer that is right for one Florida boat owner is different from the answer for another. Here are some highlights of different boat storage modes and different boat storage ideas to consider.
Types of boat storage
In-water storage
Caution: extra care necessary.
Let’s start with the easiest storage option available to everyone: in-the-water storage. If you do not care how long your vessel stays pristine, this is a great option. We suggest that you don’t store your boat this way for any length of time. Your boat will be
fully exposed
to water, which can wear away at that shiny gel coat. Should a storm occur, the vessel could also break free of its mooring and float into another person’s backyard waterway. If you absolutely have to leave your boat bobbing in the water, take care to
secure it extremely well
with lines. Hopefully, you have a plan to take it out and secure a different means of storage as soon as possible.
At-home storage
Unless you plan to
use your garage for boat storage only
, this will not work well. Trailering the boat and keeping it on the side of the house may be an option; if you choose to do that, make sure to take all items off the boat every time you park it and have a secure cover.
Lift storage
For those boat owners who use boat lifts, this is a viable means of boat storage. One of the benefits of lift storage is that the boat will be
easy to launch
; this may mean that you and your family will use it more often than you might if the vessel were at an offsite location. It takes mere seconds to lower a boat from its lofty lift perch and into the water. Within a minute or two, you and your family are then off on the next watery excursion.
Keep in mind that when storing your boat on a lift, you must take care to
properly secure it in the event of inclement weather
. A boat that is overrun by storm surge may break free of its tether. The Internet is full of shocking pictures of boats tipped half-in, half-out of the water or nudged into neighboring backyards by strong currents, wind, & tidal surge.
Platform lifts and profile lifts
are two options, and as for cost, a good rule is to expect to pay approximately $1 for every pound that the lift will have to hoist. For the sake of preparedness, this is definitely a time to overestimate your costs.
Outdoor boatyard
An outdoor boatyard is another option. It’s essentially a car lot filled with boats. Covers can be used to offer further protection. Some boatyards are adjacent to marinas, but it will likely cost less to keep your vessel in the nearby boatyard than in the marina itself.
Marina slips
Marinas offer a few options for storing your boat. One option is the
wet slip
, in which a vessel will securely float in the water. Often, this storage area is covered and offers fair protection from the elements. Still, this is a version of that in-water storage that can lead to corrosion of the paint and other wear-and-tear.
Another option is a
lift slip
, which is just what it sounds like. The boat is lifted out of the water, which helps prevent the erosion it can suffer in the water.
However, not every marina covers its lifts, meaning that the elements can affect the vessel. This can cause major problems if a storm hits and the boat is not properly secured.
High-and-dry storage
This indoor option keeps your vessel out of the sun and surf. This is ideal for those who
do not plan to use the boat on a regular basis
. It is necessary to call ahead and have someone remove your vessel from its perch before you can trailer it to the next destination. This adds another step to the preparation you must do before taking the boat out on the water, so consider whether high-and-dry storage is too much of a hassle.
Storage costs
The cost to store a boat
will vary widely
based on the type of storage and the location of the facility. The cheapest mode of storage is obviously at-home storage. The most expensive will likely be at a marina, where you often reap the benefits of on-site security along with a convenient way to launch.
No matter which way you choose to store a boat, it is
important to properly insure it
. Though Florida does not require marine insurance for boat owners, electing not to purchase a policy is a huge risk. Many destruction scenarios can happen that involve a vessel, and accidents and property loss are only two. The best course of action is to
select a marine insurance advisor
you trust to build a personalized policy plan for you.
Explore the water with confidence
W3 Insurance protects vessels so that their owners can feel confident exploring the waterways. Boating is such a joy; protect yourself for the unexpected by trusting W3 Insurance with your boat insurance requirements.
Speak with an experienced W3 marine insurance advisor and
request a quote today
.
