Yacht Hurricane Plan: A Complete Guide for Safety and Protection
April 30, 2025								    In
Boat Ownership
Hurricanes can pose a serious threat to yachts, whether they are docked in marinas or anchored offshore. The powerful winds, heavy rain, and storm surges associated with these weather phenomena can cause devastating damage. If you own a yacht in
hurricane-prone regions
, it’s crucial to be proactive and well-prepared to minimize the risk of damage and ensure the safety of both the vessel and its crew.
This guide will walk you through essential hurricane preparedness steps, address frequently asked questions, and help boaters understand insurance policies and coverage specifics.
What Is a Hurricane Plan for a Yacht?
A hurricane plan for a yacht involves detailed preparation to minimize damage during storms. It includes securing your vessel, choosing a safe location, maintaining emergency equipment, and understanding your responsibilities as outlined in your insurance policy.
1. Know the Hurricane Forecast and Stay Informed
Before you start preparing your yacht, stay up-to-date with weather reports and hurricane forecasts. The National Hurricane Center (NHC) and local meteorological agencies provide accurate and timely information regarding hurricanes. The sooner you know a storm is approaching, the more time you’ll have to take the necessary precautions.
Track the Storm:
Follow the storm’s path, intensity, and projected landfall to determine the potential impact on your location. Websites like NOAA and apps like Storm Radar give real-time updates on storm paths, intensities, projected landfalls, and storm surge risks.
Activate Alerts:
Set up notifications and alerts on weather apps, TV, or radio to receive real-time updates.
2. Secure Your Yacht’s Docking Location
If your yacht is docked in a marina or at a dock,
ensuring the docking area is prepared
for the incoming storm is critical. Here’s how you can do that.
Double Check Lines and Fenders:
Ensure that your yacht’s lines are secure and of adequate strength. Use heavy-duty dock lines, spring lines, and fender boards. Additional extra fenders provide an extra layer of protection. Ensure your lines are long enough to handle rising water or a tropical storm.
Prepare for Chafing:
Protect your ropes from wear by adding chafing gear at contact points such as pilings and cleats. These prevent rope breakage during high winds.
Remove or Reinforce Sails:
If your yacht has sails, remove them or secure them tightly to avoid damage. This will prevent the wind from catching the sails and causing damage to the mast or rigging. The same goes for dinghies, bridge enclosures, and cockpit coverings.
Tie Down Everything That Can’t Move:
Tillers, wheels, outboard motors, ladders, grills, and booms should all be secure.
Check for Docking Adequacy:
Some marinas may be susceptible to storm surges or flooding. If you suspect that your current marina won’t withstand the storm, consider relocating your yacht to a safer location or choosing a dock further inland.
3. Prepare Your Yacht’s Safety Systems
Ensuring your
yacht is prepared for the storm
involves checking its equipment and systems to ensure they are reliable.
Storm Anchors:
If your yacht is anchored offshore, use a reliable and robust storm anchor. Ensure it is the correct size and weight for your vessel. Double-check your anchor lines and ensure they are long enough to provide ample room for your yacht to swing and avoid collisions.
Check Bilge Pumps and Batteries:
Test your bilge pumps to ensure they are functioning correctly and can handle excess water in the event of a flood on your yacht. Also, check the batteries to ensure they are fully charged and can power critical systems, such as the bilge pump, lights, and communications, in case of power loss.
Secure Your Electronics:
Protect sensitive electronic devices, such as GPS, radar, and radios, by storing them in waterproof containers. This will prevent water from damaging these vital components. Alternatively, remove loose items like these to prevent damage.
Stock Emergency Supplies:
Keep your yacht well-stocked with emergency supplies, including life jackets, flares, flashlights, first aid kits, spare hoses, extra food and water, and any necessary medications.
4. Minimize the Risk of Flooding
Flooding is one of the most damaging aspects of hurricanes, so preventing water from entering your yacht is a top priority. Here’s our advice.
Check Hull for Leaks:
Inspect the hull and deck for any existing leaks or damage. Seal any gaps or cracks using marine-grade sealants to prevent water from seeping in. Ensure the drain plug is secure and adjusted properly.
Secure Hatches and Ports:
Lock down hatches, ports, and Bimini covers to prevent water from entering.
Protect Below Decks:
If possible, move any valuables or equipment stored below deck to higher levels. The bilge area should be clear to allow water to drain efficiently if needed.
5. Consider Moving Your Yacht
If the mooring location is vulnerable or prone to surges and flooding, consider moving your yacht to safer inland marinas or a boatyard. Here are some other options to consider.
Haul Out Your Yacht:
If possible, use a boat lift or jack stands to transfer your yacht to land. This is one of the most effective ways to protect your vessel from storm surges, winds, and flooding. Dry storage or shipyards are ideal choices for severe storms. However, not all marinas have facilities for hauling out yachts, so plan ahead. Once you’re in a safe place, use wheel chocks or blocks to prevent the boat from rolling.
Move to a Protected Harbor:
If hauling out is not feasible, try to move your yacht to a more sheltered harbor or a location that’s less likely to experience storm surges or high winds.  Relocate to protective bays or coves for mooring away from hurricane paths. Use additional anchors to stabilize the yacht against high winds.
Anchor Offshore:
If moving your yacht to another dock isn’t an option, consider anchoring your boat in a location that is safe from the storm’s predicted path and protected from rough waters. Double-check that the anchor can handle severe low tide or shifting currents.
6. Ensure You Have the Right Insurance Coverage
A clear understanding of your
marine insurance
ensures that you’re fully prepared for hurricane-related claims.
Review Your Boat Insurance Policy:
Inspect policy limits on your declaration page, policy terms and conditions, coverages, exclusions, and endorsements. Go over your policy’s details, including:
Coverage limits for storm surges and physical damage
Increased hurricane deductibles for named storms
Required steps as part of your hurricane plan
Salvage clauses and liabilities for damages
Named Storm Deductible May Apply:
Check if your policy has an increased hull (physical damage) deductible for hurricane damage. Many insurers will have a higher deductible for named/numbered storms.
Salvage Charges:
When a covered loss occurs and hull coverage is in place, generally, the salvage charge (if applicable) is covered under the hull/physical damage section of the policy.
Storm Plan:
A few yacht insurance policies require the yacht owner to fulfill their storm plan to be eligible for coverage.
Verify Your Coverage Location:
Where your boat is secured during a hurricane could affect your coverage. Ensure that your marina or selected location complies with your plan’s stipulations.
7. Develop an Evacuation Plan
In extreme cases, you may need to evacuate the area. Don’t leave it until the last minute—have a plan in place for yourself and your crew.
Evacuation Routes:
Familiarize yourself with nearby roads, shelters, and evacuation routes well in advance of hurricane season.
Safety First:
If you’re unable to secure your yacht in time, prioritize your personal safety. Ensure you have an evacuation plan for you and your crew, and always keep life-saving equipment, such as life jackets and a fully charged phone, on hand.
8. Be Prepared to File Claims in Case of Damage
When a loss occurs, boat owners should take prudent measures without delay to prevent further damage to their yacht and save the receipts to review with an adjuster.
Document Your Yacht:
Take detailed photos or videos of your yacht and all of its equipment before the hurricane season begins. This documentation can help in the claims process if you need to file a loss after the storm.
Notify Your Insurance Company:
If your yacht has been affected by a hurricane, it’s crucial to act swiftly and efficiently when contacting your insurance company. Here’s a simple guide to help you navigate the claims process:
Be Clear and Detailed:
When speaking with the claims adjuster, be thorough in describing the damage. Provide all the necessary documentation, including photographs, a list of damages, and any other evidence required. The more precise you are, the faster the claims process will go.
Understand the Next Steps:
Ask your insurer about the next steps, including when an adjuster will assess the damage, what forms or documents are needed, and how long the process will take. This will give you a better idea of what to expect.
Follow Up Regularly:
Stay in touch with your insurance company to track the status of your claim. Regular follow-ups can ensure that your case is moving forward and that any additional information needed is provided in a timely manner.
Final Tips for Hurricane Season
Preparing your yacht for a hurricane is no small task, but taking the proper precautions can help protect your vessel from severe damage. From securing your yacht in a safe location to ensuring your safety systems are functioning, each step you take will increase the likelihood of your yacht surviving the storm. Always stay informed, and don’t hesitate to evacuate if necessary. With the proper preparation and planning, you can face hurricane season with peace of mind knowing you’ve done everything you can to protect your yacht and crew.
Hurricane prep isn’t just about protecting assets. It’s about prioritizing safety, both for your yacht and all who sail aboard it. If you require additional guidance or want to ensure your boat insurance aligns with comprehensive hurricane protection,
contact WWW Marine Insurance
.
Stay safe and be proactive when it comes to hurricane preparation—your yacht will thank you for it!
Request a Quote
FAQs
How do I create an effective hurricane plan for my yacht?
Start with routine maintenance, review insurance coverage, and outline specific actions to take during hurricane season.
What happens if I cannot follow my hurricane plan?
Notify your insurer immediately. Some policies may still offer partial coverage, but failure to meet critical requirements could result in non-payment of claims.
Is my dock address the same as my mailing address for insurance purposes?
It’s essential to confirm this with your insurer. The location of your yacht during the storm often affects coverage.

Everything You Need to Know to Own a Boat in Florida
August 12, 2022								    In
Boat Insurance
Boat Ownership
Florida Boating
The state of Florida is made up of close to 19% water. From the marshy Everglades to the tarpon-rich waters near Boca Grande, it’s a boater’s paradise. Join the ranks of those discovering the restorative nature of boat life.
Here is everything you need to know about owning a boat in Florida.
Basic Boat Safety Tips
The number one most important element to consider when purchasing a boat in Florida is the boating prowess of the owner. That’s right: before you consider engines, hulls, power poles, or any navigational equipment, be honest about your experience level and your commitment to the craft. Purchase a boat you are comfortable captaining. A vessel that is too large, or that demands more than your training level, may leave you sitting on the shore, uncertain. Research the different types of boats thoroughly and select one that you feel confident driving.
Having a high level of confidence regarding the craft you captain is the most basic of basic boat safety tips. The next ‘must have’ element for every boat owner is the
boat safety kit
, which should always remain aboard.
Just as a Florida homeowner is advised to keep a hurricane preparedness kit just in case, so too must the Florida boat owner have a selection of items that help in the event of an accident or loss of power.
Common safety kit items
Flashlight (and batteries)
– Should your vessel break down in the nighttime hours, you’ll be glad to have the illumination.
Emergency radio
– We’ve all been in situations without a phone charger when we really need it. The emergency radio is there even if your cell phone isn’t – a link between you and those on shore.
Mirror for signaling and whistle for alerting
– Hold a mirror up to the sun, and you can deflect that sunlight far away. Even if your electronic equipment fails, that signal can be seen for miles. A whistle is a simple object that can help to alert others of your presence and need for help.
Properly prepared first aid kit
– There are many different types of first aid kits. Compile your own or purchase a kit specifically packed for Florida boaters. Inside, you’ll find the usual bandages, ointments, etc. We recommend adding sunscreen to the mix (that Florida sun can be brutal, and if you’re stranded, you’ll be glad to have it).
Fire extinguisher and garbage bags
– The need for the fire extinguisher is apparent, but garbage bags? – Yes, they are a worthy addition to the Florida boater safety kit. Use garbage bags as ponchos if it rains or to help conserve heat in cold weather.
Life jackets
– There needs to be one
life jacket
for every person aboard, regardless of age, even if they are expert swimmers. They should be approved by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Duct tape, buckets, and ropes
– Duct tape might not fix everything, but it can plug a small leak and give you enough time to get your craft back to shore. A simple bucket plays an important role if you need to bail out. And ropes are a must on any craft, at least to tie up to docks and rescue an overboard passenger.
Now that you have the items necessary to make up a Florida boat safety kit, it’s time to educate yourself regarding active, in-the-moment boat safety practices. Hopefully, if you follow the guidance of your boating safety class, you will never need the safety kit at all.
Recommended Boating Safety Courses
Did you know that you are
required to take a boat safety course
? If you are operating a motorized boat of more than 10 horsepower and were born during or after 1988, you are required to do so – an important part of keeping our waterways safe.
Look for a course that is Florida-approved; different options exist, including online selections. We suggest this one from
Boat Ed
. You can also peruse the list curated by the
Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission
for a solid list of options.
After you’ve aced your Florida boating safety course, make sure you know what to do if your boat breaks down or is involved in an accident. Knowledge gives peace of mind–that’s why we’ve compiled this boating accident and breakdown guide for a quick snapshot regarding what to do if your Florida boat runs into trouble.
Boating Accident and Breakdown Guide
Should a boating accident or breakdown occur, do an immediate check of everyone aboard for injury and to see what medical attention, if any, is needed. Break out the Florida boat first aid kit and tend to any wounds. Then, call for help using your cell phone or the emergency radio aboard.
What to do when involved in a boating accident
Document
the moment as much as possible. In the frenzy of stress that always accompanies a boating accident, major details can be lost. Take pictures of any damage and, instead of writing things down, you can dictate what happened and save the recording in your phone.
Determine if the U.S. Coast Guard should be notified
.
Call your marine insurance agent
and let them know what has happened. Hopefully, you’ve opted for comprehensive insurance protection that has you, your passengers, and your beloved boat covered.
What to do in the event of a breakdown
Try to move your craft out of the way
, if possible, if you are on a heavily-traveled waterway. This could save your boat from a collision.
Call the nearest harbor master,
or break out the emergency radio and call for help. Different tow services exist to help boaters who are stranded, or the Coast Guard may come to your aid if appropriate.
Where to store your boat
It’s important to know what to do
on
the water, but how are you protecting your boat when you’re
not
exploring the Florida waterways? There are several options available to you.
Storing your boat in Florida is quite easy. You could leave it outside your residence–keeping the vessel nearby and avoiding marina fees There are some drawbacks to this commonsense approach, however.
Exposing your craft to the elements
is a surefire way for it to deteriorate more quickly. A pervasive example of this is upholstery. Even the most watertight boat cushions are going to eventually disintegrate, and the more you expose a boat to the elements, the quicker this will occur. You could keep your boat in the garage, of course, but the vessel will take up most of that valuable storage and parking space.
Lift storage
Perhaps you have a lift outside your home, ready for your boat to be perched and lowered. This is a solid Florida boat storage selection, but make sure that if a hurricane or tropical storm looms, you’ve taken the necessary precautions to keep that on-site boat secured.
Marina storage
Storage at a marina is another viable way to keep your boat safe and at the ready for future voyages. Often, marinas will offer security details–but you should still never keep expensive equipment aboard when storing your boat.
For those who don’t live on the water, or who don’t want to keep a boat on their property, a marina can be a wonderful choice. Before you select one, make sure to thoroughly understand their
rules and regulations
, especially how easy (or difficult) it will be to access your craft whenever you’d like.
Dry stack storage
In dry stacking, boats are placed on racks, often indoors and away from the elements. To retrieve your boat, you’ll need to call the storage facility ahead of time and have it lowered and prepared to move safely to your trailer via forklift. This storage option is attractive to those who boat rarely or don’t reside in Florida permanently.
Boatyard storage
Boatyard storage is a hybrid Florida boat storage option that combines dry stack storage with near-marina storage. In this case, the stacked boats are kept outside but not necessarily on the water. This is less expensive than marina storage and keeps you relatively close to an embarkation point. You’ll need to follow the same call-ahead process you’d use when dry docking.
No matter which Florida boat storage mode you select, resist the impulse to keep the vessel in the water for an extended period of time. Salt water is highly corrosive to boats and, for those not in salt water, weather damage can be catastrophic. At the very least, lift the boat out of the water and remove any electronic equipment and valuables after every excursion.
Importance of marine insurance
Florida marine insurance is so absolutely vital. When it comes to everything you need to know to own a boat in this beautiful state, understanding marine insurance ranks near the top of requirements for safe boating.
Marine insurance is the ultimate protection for your vessel. Consider it a sort of ‘invisible life jacket’ you carry with you as you navigate the waterways. Before you ever load the fishing gear and cooler, stock the first aid kit, or chart that first Sunshine State boating excursion, you must protect yourself, your passengers, and your vessel from the unexpected. No one can predict the future–but marine insurance can safeguard you against many unexpected troubles.
Things to consider when purchasing Florida marine insurance
Insurance cost
depends on the type of vessel, the surrounding environment, the contents aboard, and how you’ll use the boat. You will want to consider physical damage coverage and liability while also considering optimal coverages available to you.
Call an experienced advisor
to compile a
personalized policy
, as it is easy to miss a vital part of insurance protection. A marine insurance advisor considers multiple elements before ever suggesting a policy.
If an accident were to occur
, would your passengers’ medical care be covered? Who is liable for those injury-related costs? Your marine insurance advisor can help answer these questions and propose solutions.
Prepare for the worst and hope for the best.
That’s what Florida marine insurance is there for– to protect you and your craft in a worst-case scenario, while allowing you to go on every voyage with the calm that comes from that protection.
Stay Protected with W3 Insurance
Florida marine insurance is the ultimate life jacket. Cover your vessel and those aboard, and set off to explore the Sunshine State’s famous waterways. Stay covered with help from W3 Marine Insurance–and bon voyage! Speak with an experienced marine insurance advisor and
request a quote today
.

Short version privacy policy:
we won’t share your email with anyone.
Long, but not so boring privacy policy
Free chapters you get:
A Simple Way to Decide Between Lithium or Lead-Acid Batteries for a Cruising Boat
With all the claims and counterclaims for the two chemistries, how on earth do we make the right decision? Good news, it’s not hard.
Hull Materials, Which Is Best?
One of the common debates in any sailor’s bar is which hull material is best. John settles the argument…it depends. But he does make some solid recommendations for hull materials most of us should avoid and the one that the majority should choose.
15 Steps To Getting Securely Anchored
When thinking about anchoring, it’s easy to just focus on gear, but good technique can contribute at least as much to getting securely anchored. These steps, based on 40 years of experience, make getting securely anchored easy and repeatable.
10 Tips to Make Coming Alongside (Docking) Easy
These tips, which we have developed over two decades of coming alongside double-handed in a 56-foot boat without a bow thruster, will take the stress out of docking and make it easy…even fun too.
Reefing Made Easy
How to reef a sailboat easily and quickly without getting frightened or wet.
4 Vital Anchor Selection Criteria and a Review of SPADE
Everyone loves to tout the benefits of their favourite anchor, John included, but this article is about much more: how to cut through all the claims to the criteria that really matter when selecting an anchor.
12 Tips To Avoid Ruining Our Easily Driven Sailboat
We bought a lovely easily driven offshore cruising sailboat, but it’s all too easy to screw her up if we don’t heed these tips.
11 Things We Do To Stay Rational About Safety
We write a lot about safety here at AAC: crew overboard, storm survival, fire at sea, etc. All important stuff, but we worry about how this affects our primary goal here at Attainable Adventure Cruising of helping you go cruising. So here’s how we balance safety with actually getting out there.
Banishing Sidedeck Jacklines Forever
We have shown that sidedeck jacklines are deeply flawed and may even be more dangerous than no jacklines at all, due to drag risk and the false sense of security they confer. But can we get rid of them and still work our boats efficiently? Yes, we can! Here’s how, with video proof.
Stopping Wave Strikes While Heaved-To
Some of the options that we can use to solve the dangerous problem of wave strikes while heaved-to that I described in the last chapter.

Attainable Adventure Cruising
The Offshore Voyaging Reference Site
About
New
Books
Topics
Making cruising easier, more fun, less expensive, and safer, for
over 20 years
.
Over 5000 paying members can’t be wrong.
Join Today
Learn More
Join us to get:
12 Online Books
We create, organize and continually update the information that matters most to you: Anchoring, Docking, Heavy Weather, etc.
Over 1500 Articles and Tips
Over the last 20 years we have written about most everything you need to know.
New Tips, Articles and Book Chapters Every Month
Offshore voyaging and coastal cruising change constantly and we keep up.
Unbiased Information
We don’t accept advertising or kickbacks from YouTube, nor do we use affiliate links.
We work exclusively for our members.
Discussion
The most knowledgable cruising community on the internet:
discuss, ask questions, share your wisdom.
“…you won’t find a finer resource for voyaging information anywhere, at any price.”
John Harries and AAC speak the capital “T” Truth about ocean sailing that you won’t find in any magazine, with a proper focus on fundamentals first. AAC espouses seamanship at its best—you won’t find a finer resource for voyaging information anywhere, at any price.
Andy Schell
professional sailor
“I recommend your site to everybody, keep up the good work.”
John Kretschmer
professional sailor
“A great resource…”
Steve Dashew
legendary voyager, designer and builder
“John and Phyllis take a particularly scientific approach to problem solving.”
…the breadth and depth of knowledge contained within the Attainable Adventure Cruising site is unmatched by any other resource I know. Moreover, John and Phyllis take a particularly scientific approach to problem solving. Rather than relying on the anecdotes of their own experiences, sound as they may be, they incorporate into their articles contemporary research and other expert opinion so as to give the sailor a complete and thorough guide to cruising
Randall Reeves
two time Southern Ocean circumnavigator
“serious depth of experience and methodical approach”
What really shines through with Attainable Adventure Cruising content is a serious depth of experience and methodical approach to the vexing questions and challenges cruisers must address.
John Neal
sail-training expedition leader, mahina.com
Online Books
All For US$3.00/Month

Dangers such as, but not limited to, extreme weather, cold, ice, lack of help or assistance, gear failure, grounding, and falling overboard could injure or kill you and wreck your boat. Decisions such as, but not limited to, heading offshore, where you go, and how you equip your boat, are yours and yours alone. The information on this web site is based on what has worked for the authors in the past, but that does not mean it will work for you, or that it is the best, or even a good way for you to do things.

/Month—$120/Year
Join
Questions?
Gift Membership
Frequently Asked Questions
Can I learn more before I join?
Right Here
Do you have a warranty?
Of course,
if within 7 days you are not entirely satisfied, we will give you your money back, no questions asked.
Do I get a warning before Annual Membership auto-renewal?
Of course
, we are not sleazy.
Will the price go up when I renew?
If you select Annual or Supporter you keep your original price. If you select 1 Year, the price will be the current price at each renewal.
What if, after the first year, I wanted to cancel, but forgot?
If Annual membership, you will be charged, BUT not to worry,  just email us
within 45 days of the charge
and we will refund the entire payment—
can’t be fairer than that!
Can I gift AAC membership?
Of course you can, you nice person, you. Just click on the icon to make someone’s cruising dreams come true…OK, that might be a bit of a stretch, but membership will help.
What currency do you bill in?
We bill in
US dollars
because that’s the currency most of our expenses are in.
But If you know what a toque is and who first said “elbows up”…and live in Canada…we pay the HST for you, all 14% of it (we are a Nova Scotia company).​
How safe is my credit card with you?
Very.
We don’t store or even see your credit card
. We leave that to the professionals at Stripe and PayPal. As far as we know, and we did some deep Google searching, neither company has ever been hacked.
I have a different question.
No problem, we are here for you:
*protected email*
Join
Supporter membership was frequently requested by those who felt that we did not charge enough for our content.

Marine Insurance Insights
Explore our collection of articles that provide insights into the world of marine insurance.
Latest News & Updates
Stay ahead of industry trends and developments by keeping up with the latest news in marine insurance. Our selected articles cover a broad range of topics, including policy changes, innovative insurance solutions, and case studies that highlight the dynamic aspects of marine insurance.
Whether you're a broker, agent, or someone interested in the intricacies of marine insurance, our blog offers valuable information to enrich your understanding and help you navigate this specialized field. Regularly updated, our content ensures you remain informed about critical updates and insights.
Learn More
Q&A: Navigating Boat Insurance with Insights from Neil Hiller
This article provides a comprehensive guide to boat insurance, covering essential topics like available coverage options, key factors influencing premiums, and practical tips for boat owners. Whether you're looking to insure a speedboat, cruiser, or yacht, this Q&A-style guide answers common questions and offers expert advice to help you choose the right policy and navigate the unique aspects of marine insurance.
Read more
Why Regular Boat Maintenance is Crucial for Insurance Claims: A Guide for Australian Boat Owners and Brokers
Regular boat maintenance is crucial for ensuring the safety and longevity of your vessel, as well as protecting your insurance coverage. This article explains how neglecting upkeep can impact insurance claims, highlights key areas of maintenance, and offers practical tips for boat owners and brokers to keep boats seaworthy and claims valid.
Read more
Emerging Trends in Marine Insurance 2024: What Brokers and Clients Should Know
This article explores the emerging trends impacting the marine insurance industry, such as stricter environmental regulations, advances in technology, climate change risks, geopolitical tensions, and global economic pressures. It provides insights for brokers and clients on how these factors affect coverage and risk management, offering practical advice on navigating the evolving maritime landscape.
Read more
View All Articles

Table of Contents
Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for

Table of Contents
Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for
Boat insurance costs and discounts
Where to buy boat insurance
Your prized boat probably didn’t come cheap. Whether you own a bass fishing boat or a yacht, it’s important to find the right boat insurance that will come to the rescue if you have damage or theft. Here’s how to understand boat insurance policies.
Do you need boat insurance?
Your
home insurance
policy covers your boat in some cases, but it doesn’t go far. Homeowners policies typically cap boat coverage at $1,000 or 10% of your home’s insured value. And liability coverage — which pays for damage your boat does to others — typically isn’t included under home insurance. So a home insurance policy might help you only if your boat is small, slow and inexpensive.
At a glance: Do I need boat insurance?
Yes
No
Yachts.
Large sailboats.
Jet boats.
Personal watercraft like WaveRunners.
Anything that runs faster than 25 mph.
Canoes.
Boats with small engines.
Any other small, slow, inexpensive boat.
What boat insurance will pay for
You can typically buy liability insurance — which pays for damage your boat does to others — in amounts from $15,000 to $300,000, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Here's what else you can expect from a policy:
What boat insurance typically covers
What it doesn’t cover
Damage or destruction from a collision, fire, lightning, theft and vandalism.
Damage to a boat and permanently attached equipment, such as anchors.
Bodily injury liability, which pays expenses when someone is injured on your boat.
Property damage liability, which pays for damage your boat causes to someone else’s property.
Guest passenger liability, which pays for legal expenses of someone driving your boat with permission.
Medical payments, which pay expenses for you and your passengers.
Normal wear and tear.
Defective machinery or machinery damage.
Damage from sharks and other creatures.
Damage from mold, insects and zebra mussels.
Check, too, about additional coverage for trailers and accessories, for towing and for damage caused by an uninsured boater.
You can buy two types of damage coverage for a boat:
Actual cash value.
This pays the value of your boat at the time of the damage. If your boat is destroyed, your insurance company determines its market value.
Agreed amount value.
If your boat is destroyed, your insurer pays you an amount that you and the company agreed on beforehand. If your boat can be repaired, your insurer replaces old items for new ones without deducting for depreciation.
It’s also important to understand what your boat insurance covers before heading out on the water, says Todd Shasha, boat and yacht personal insurance director at Travelers Insurance. He recommends checking whether your policy can cover these scenarios:
Mechanical breakdown coverage.
Pays to repair or replace your outboard motor as long as it’s not due to wear and tear.
Salvage.
If your boat becomes disabled and a basic tow won’t help, you might need to call a salvage company to recover it. Typically a salvage company will ask for a percentage of the boat’s value as payment, which can be quite expensive. Not all insurance companies offer this coverage.
Gadgets.
Not all boat insurers cover expensive accessories like fishing equipment or fancy coolers unless they’re permanently attached to the boat. For example, Travelers offers personal property coverage that pays you if they’re stolen or lost while out on the water. Endorsements, which are additions to your policy, are available if you want to increase the value of your personal property limits.
Some important things to know about boating and your policy:
Navigational limits:
If you own a yacht or a larger boat, your policy will have limits outlining where you can navigate your vessel. If you venture outside of the territory you agreed to in the policy, your insurance may not cover you. Typically, the broader your navigation area is, the higher your insurance costs will be.
Layup periods:
Taking your boat out of the water is typical during cold weather, and most insurance companies will give you a credit because it’s not being used. But take the boat out for a spin before the layup period ends and you won’t be covered by your insurance policy.
Marine inspections:
If your boat is an older model, most insurance companies will want you to have it inspected by a marine surveyor in order to assess the vessel’s condition and market value. For safety’s sake, consider a marine survey even if it’s not required.
Underage operators:
You might be tempted to let your 12-year-old drive the boat every now and then. But if your child doesn't meet age and license requirements in your state, your boat insurance policy might not cover you.  Age and license requirements for operating personal watercraft vary from state to state. In Virginia and Florida, for example, no one under 14 may operate a personal watercraft. In Texas, children under 13 are barred from driving one unless a licensed operator who's at least 18 is on board. For requirements where you live, check with the boating regulatory agency in your state.
Boat insurance costs and discounts
How much you’ll pay for boat insurance depends on the level of insurance coverage you want, as well as the size, horsepower, type and value of your boat.
You can choose your deductible, which is the amount deducted from your insurance check if you make a claim. A typical policy has deductibles of $250 for property damage, $500 for theft and $1,000 for medical payments, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Liability claims against you do not have a deductible.
Insurance companies offer a variety of ways to save money, including discounts for:
Having a diesel-powered boat.
Not having made a previous boat insurance claim.
Carrying other policies, such as car or homeowners, with the same insurer.
Taking safety courses.
Where to buy boat insurance
Boat insurance is widely available. NerdWallet looked at the top 25 auto insurance sellers in the country and found these that also offer boat insurance:
AAA
Offers coverage for boats up to $250,000 in value.
AAA lowers your deductible by 25% each time you renew your policy and haven’t had a claim.
Allstate
Average cost of boat insurance from Allstate is about $20 a month, according to Allstate.
Bundle boat insurance with an Allstate homeowners policy and you qualify for up to a 20% discount.
American Family Insurance
Additional coverage options cover personal items and pay for repairs to your boat and equipment, without a deduction for depreciation.
Amica
If your boat is disabled, an Amica policy covers towing to nearest port.
If your yacht can’t be repaired, Amica pays to replace it with a new one, without subtracting depreciation.
Auto-Owners
Optional boat insurance coverage is available through homeowners policies.
Country Financial
Country Financial homeowners insurance covers your boat for up to $1,500.
You can buy more coverage under your homeowners policy.
Erie
Erie’s standard Boat Protector Policy comes with extras, including payments up to $500 to fix or replace boating equipment and accessories, and payments up to $250 for emergency towing. (Not available in Kentucky.)
Farmers
Farmers offers seven packages to fit your vessel type and coverage needs.
Geico
Geico’s optional premium boat towing service offers unlimited on-water towing (within 25 miles of an approved tower) and pays the service provider directly.
Geico offers several discounts, including one for passing a boat-safety course and for maintaining a good driving record.
Hanover
You can cover your boat, sailboat or personal watercraft with an endorsement to your Hanover Platinum or Connections homeowners insurance policy.
The Hartford
Additional coverage, which costs extra, is available for your accessories, trailer and boat hull.
Liberty Mutual
You must have a homeowners insurance policy with Liberty Mutual to get boat and watercraft insurance.
MetLife
Optional coverage includes hurricane protection, which pays up to $250 to move your boat out of danger during a hurricane advisory.
Unforeseen emergency services coverage pays $250 for towing and other services on land or in the water.
Nationwide
Personal watercraft coverage includes liability, collision, comprehensive, uninsured or underinsured operator, and medical payments.
Optional towing and labor also available.
Progressive
Total loss replacement coverage pays for a new boat if your new boat is a total loss within five years of adding the coverage.
Progressive offers several specialized coverage options, including 24-hour roadside assistance if your car breaks down while towing your boat.
Unlike some insurers, Progressive doesn’t require you to submit a navigation plan. Nor does it require an inspection of your boat.
State Farm
State Farm’s optional emergency service pays up to $500 to service your boat, motor or boat trailer.
Optional wreck-removal coverage pays “reasonable expenses” to raise or remove your boat when it’s required by law.
Travelers
Travelers splits the cost to move the vessel to safety when you carry “hurricane-escape reimbursement” coverage, which costs extra.
Antique boats get the same comprehensive coverage available in Travelers' basic policy.
USAA
USAA members get a 5% discount on boat insurance, but the discount is not available in all states.
USAA is open only to active and retired military and their families.
Juan Castillo is a former staff writer at NerdWallet.

If your goal is to save some cash — perhaps by dining in more than you dine out — in the new year, Discover’s latest 5% cash-back categories can incentivize those financial resolutions.
From Jan. 1 to March 31, 2026, holders of eligible cards like the
Discover it® Cash Back
and the
Discover it® Student Cash Back
will earn 5% back on up to $1,500 in combined spending at grocery stores, wholesale clubs and select streaming services (activation required; all other purchases earn 1% back).
Here’s what’s in store.
Discover’s Q1 2026 bonus cash-back categories
Grocery stores
Grocery store purchases that are eligible for the elevated rate include those made at supermarkets, meat lockers, bakeries, smaller grocery stores and grocery delivery services. Purchases made at convenience stores and discount stores may not qualify, but they can still earn the base rewards rate on a Discover card. Any spending at Walmart or Target will earn 1% back only.
» MORE:
See our best credit cards for groceries
Wholesale clubs
If your Discover card is accepted at a wholesale club, you can earn bonus cash back on purchases there. Notably, however, Costco doesn't accept Discover cards. Wholesale club services like delivery services, travel and cell phone plans also won’t earn the bonus rate. Individual merchants and stand-alone stores located within the wholesale clubs or online may not qualify either.
» MORE:
See our best credit cards for Costco purchases
Select streaming services
This category is a repeat from Discover’s first-quarter picks of 2025. You can earn bonus cash back on services like Amazon Music, Amazon Prime Video, AMC+, Apple Music, Apple TV, Audible, DirecTV Stream, Fandango at Home, Google Play Music and Video, Max, iHeartRadio, MLB.TV, Netflix, Pandora, Paramount Plus, Peacock, SiriusXM, Sling TV, Spotify, Starz, YouTube Music, YouTube Premium, YouTube TV and other qualifying popular streaming services. Keep in mind that if your subscription or add-ons are part of a bundle with another product or service, or are billed by a third party, they may not qualify for bonus cash back.
» MORE:
See our best credit cards for streaming services
A look at 2025 categories
Discover has been known to repeat some categories from prior years. There's no telling what the future will reward, but it's worth revisiting the past to get a better understanding of the types of categories that are traditionally on the calendar:
Discover bonus rewards categories for 2026
Q1 (Jan. 1-March 31)
Grocery stores.
Wholesale clubs.
Select streaming services.
Q2 (April 1–June 30)
TBD.
(In 2025: Grocery stores; wholesale clubs.)
Q3 (July 1–Sept. 30)
TBD.
(In 2025: Gas stations/EV charging; public transit; utilities.)
Q4 (Oct. 1–Dec. 31)
TBD.
(In 2025: Amazon.com; drugstores.)
» MORE:
Current bonus categories for other 5%-back cards

Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for

Table of Contents
Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for
Boat insurance costs and discounts
Where to buy boat insurance
Your prized boat probably didn’t come cheap. Whether you own a bass fishing boat or a yacht, it’s important to find the right boat insurance that will come to the rescue if you have damage or theft. Here’s how to understand boat insurance policies.
Do you need boat insurance?
Your
home insurance
policy covers your boat in some cases, but it doesn’t go far. Homeowners policies typically cap boat coverage at $1,000 or 10% of your home’s insured value. And liability coverage — which pays for damage your boat does to others — typically isn’t included under home insurance. So a home insurance policy might help you only if your boat is small, slow and inexpensive.
At a glance: Do I need boat insurance?
Yes
No
Yachts.
Large sailboats.
Jet boats.
Personal watercraft like WaveRunners.
Anything that runs faster than 25 mph.
Canoes.
Boats with small engines.
Any other small, slow, inexpensive boat.
What boat insurance will pay for
You can typically buy liability insurance — which pays for damage your boat does to others — in amounts from $15,000 to $300,000, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Here's what else you can expect from a policy:
What boat insurance typically covers
What it doesn’t cover
Damage or destruction from a collision, fire, lightning, theft and vandalism.
Damage to a boat and permanently attached equipment, such as anchors.
Bodily injury liability, which pays expenses when someone is injured on your boat.
Property damage liability, which pays for damage your boat causes to someone else’s property.
Guest passenger liability, which pays for legal expenses of someone driving your boat with permission.
Medical payments, which pay expenses for you and your passengers.
Normal wear and tear.
Defective machinery or machinery damage.
Damage from sharks and other creatures.
Damage from mold, insects and zebra mussels.
Check, too, about additional coverage for trailers and accessories, for towing and for damage caused by an uninsured boater.
You can buy two types of damage coverage for a boat:
Actual cash value.
This pays the value of your boat at the time of the damage. If your boat is destroyed, your insurance company determines its market value.
Agreed amount value.
If your boat is destroyed, your insurer pays you an amount that you and the company agreed on beforehand. If your boat can be repaired, your insurer replaces old items for new ones without deducting for depreciation.
It’s also important to understand what your boat insurance covers before heading out on the water, says Todd Shasha, boat and yacht personal insurance director at Travelers Insurance. He recommends checking whether your policy can cover these scenarios:
Mechanical breakdown coverage.
Pays to repair or replace your outboard motor as long as it’s not due to wear and tear.
Salvage.
If your boat becomes disabled and a basic tow won’t help, you might need to call a salvage company to recover it. Typically a salvage company will ask for a percentage of the boat’s value as payment, which can be quite expensive. Not all insurance companies offer this coverage.
Gadgets.
Not all boat insurers cover expensive accessories like fishing equipment or fancy coolers unless they’re permanently attached to the boat. For example, Travelers offers personal property coverage that pays you if they’re stolen or lost while out on the water. Endorsements, which are additions to your policy, are available if you want to increase the value of your personal property limits.
Some important things to know about boating and your policy:
Navigational limits:
If you own a yacht or a larger boat, your policy will have limits outlining where you can navigate your vessel. If you venture outside of the territory you agreed to in the policy, your insurance may not cover you. Typically, the broader your navigation area is, the higher your insurance costs will be.
Layup periods:
Taking your boat out of the water is typical during cold weather, and most insurance companies will give you a credit because it’s not being used. But take the boat out for a spin before the layup period ends and you won’t be covered by your insurance policy.
Marine inspections:
If your boat is an older model, most insurance companies will want you to have it inspected by a marine surveyor in order to assess the vessel’s condition and market value. For safety’s sake, consider a marine survey even if it’s not required.
Underage operators:
You might be tempted to let your 12-year-old drive the boat every now and then. But if your child doesn't meet age and license requirements in your state, your boat insurance policy might not cover you.  Age and license requirements for operating personal watercraft vary from state to state. In Virginia and Florida, for example, no one under 14 may operate a personal watercraft. In Texas, children under 13 are barred from driving one unless a licensed operator who's at least 18 is on board. For requirements where you live, check with the boating regulatory agency in your state.
Boat insurance costs and discounts
How much you’ll pay for boat insurance depends on the level of insurance coverage you want, as well as the size, horsepower, type and value of your boat.
You can choose your deductible, which is the amount deducted from your insurance check if you make a claim. A typical policy has deductibles of $250 for property damage, $500 for theft and $1,000 for medical payments, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Liability claims against you do not have a deductible.
Insurance companies offer a variety of ways to save money, including discounts for:
Having a diesel-powered boat.
Not having made a previous boat insurance claim.
Carrying other policies, such as car or homeowners, with the same insurer.
Taking safety courses.
Where to buy boat insurance
Boat insurance is widely available. NerdWallet looked at the top 25 auto insurance sellers in the country and found these that also offer boat insurance:
AAA
Offers coverage for boats up to $250,000 in value.
AAA lowers your deductible by 25% each time you renew your policy and haven’t had a claim.
Allstate
Average cost of boat insurance from Allstate is about $20 a month, according to Allstate.
Bundle boat insurance with an Allstate homeowners policy and you qualify for up to a 20% discount.
American Family Insurance
Additional coverage options cover personal items and pay for repairs to your boat and equipment, without a deduction for depreciation.
Amica
If your boat is disabled, an Amica policy covers towing to nearest port.
If your yacht can’t be repaired, Amica pays to replace it with a new one, without subtracting depreciation.
Auto-Owners
Optional boat insurance coverage is available through homeowners policies.
Country Financial
Country Financial homeowners insurance covers your boat for up to $1,500.
You can buy more coverage under your homeowners policy.
Erie
Erie’s standard Boat Protector Policy comes with extras, including payments up to $500 to fix or replace boating equipment and accessories, and payments up to $250 for emergency towing. (Not available in Kentucky.)
Farmers
Farmers offers seven packages to fit your vessel type and coverage needs.
Geico
Geico’s optional premium boat towing service offers unlimited on-water towing (within 25 miles of an approved tower) and pays the service provider directly.
Geico offers several discounts, including one for passing a boat-safety course and for maintaining a good driving record.
Hanover
You can cover your boat, sailboat or personal watercraft with an endorsement to your Hanover Platinum or Connections homeowners insurance policy.
The Hartford
Additional coverage, which costs extra, is available for your accessories, trailer and boat hull.
Liberty Mutual
You must have a homeowners insurance policy with Liberty Mutual to get boat and watercraft insurance.
MetLife
Optional coverage includes hurricane protection, which pays up to $250 to move your boat out of danger during a hurricane advisory.
Unforeseen emergency services coverage pays $250 for towing and other services on land or in the water.
Nationwide
Personal watercraft coverage includes liability, collision, comprehensive, uninsured or underinsured operator, and medical payments.
Optional towing and labor also available.
Progressive
Total loss replacement coverage pays for a new boat if your new boat is a total loss within five years of adding the coverage.
Progressive offers several specialized coverage options, including 24-hour roadside assistance if your car breaks down while towing your boat.
Unlike some insurers, Progressive doesn’t require you to submit a navigation plan. Nor does it require an inspection of your boat.
State Farm
State Farm’s optional emergency service pays up to $500 to service your boat, motor or boat trailer.
Optional wreck-removal coverage pays “reasonable expenses” to raise or remove your boat when it’s required by law.
Travelers
Travelers splits the cost to move the vessel to safety when you carry “hurricane-escape reimbursement” coverage, which costs extra.
Antique boats get the same comprehensive coverage available in Travelers' basic policy.
USAA
USAA members get a 5% discount on boat insurance, but the discount is not available in all states.
USAA is open only to active and retired military and their families.
Juan Castillo is a former staff writer at NerdWallet.

New SoFi Charge Card Earns Unlimited 5% Back at Grocery Stores

SoFi Bank's latest card launch may be welcome news for those who make frequent supermarket sweeps.
The new $0-annual-fee SoFi Smart Card earns an uncapped 5% cash back at grocery stores, which is among the best rates on the market in one of the biggest spending categories for many shoppers. Technically, you earn 5 SoFi "reward points" per $1, but those points are worth 1 cent each. Redemption options include a deposit into a SoFi checking and savings account, a statement credit, or as payment toward any SoFi loans.
However, there are some caveats to be aware of:
Because it's a
charge card
and not a credit card, you won’t be able to carry a balance on the SoFi Smart Card and must instead pay it off in full each month.
Secondly, while the card doesn’t have an annual fee, you must have a SoFi checking and savings account and a SoFi Plus membership, which costs $10 a month. (Your account balances determine your spending limit with the card.) You'd need to spend at least $200 a month at grocery stores using the SoFi Smart Card to earn enough in rewards to offset that membership cost.
The card doesn’t earn rewards on any other purchases.
On the plus side, there’s no
hard credit pull
required to apply for the SoFi Smart Card, which protects your credit scores from the temporary dip that can happen from a credit inquiry.
Another unique feature of the SoFi Smart Card is how it’s integrated with the cardholder’s checking and savings account to prevent overspending. When a purchase is made with the SoFi Smart Card, the amount of that purchase is “reserved," meaning those funds are no longer accessible to make other purchases until the card balance is paid.
It's similar, in some ways, to how a debit card works. But unlike a debit card, the SoFi Smart Card reports to all
three major U.S. credit bureaus
, so it can help you build your credit.

Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for

Table of Contents
Do you need boat insurance?
What boat insurance will pay for
Boat insurance costs and discounts
Where to buy boat insurance
Your prized boat probably didn’t come cheap. Whether you own a bass fishing boat or a yacht, it’s important to find the right boat insurance that will come to the rescue if you have damage or theft. Here’s how to understand boat insurance policies.
Do you need boat insurance?
Your
home insurance
policy covers your boat in some cases, but it doesn’t go far. Homeowners policies typically cap boat coverage at $1,000 or 10% of your home’s insured value. And liability coverage — which pays for damage your boat does to others — typically isn’t included under home insurance. So a home insurance policy might help you only if your boat is small, slow and inexpensive.
At a glance: Do I need boat insurance?
Yes
No
Yachts.
Large sailboats.
Jet boats.
Personal watercraft like WaveRunners.
Anything that runs faster than 25 mph.
Canoes.
Boats with small engines.
Any other small, slow, inexpensive boat.
What boat insurance will pay for
You can typically buy liability insurance — which pays for damage your boat does to others — in amounts from $15,000 to $300,000, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Here's what else you can expect from a policy:
What boat insurance typically covers
What it doesn’t cover
Damage or destruction from a collision, fire, lightning, theft and vandalism.
Damage to a boat and permanently attached equipment, such as anchors.
Bodily injury liability, which pays expenses when someone is injured on your boat.
Property damage liability, which pays for damage your boat causes to someone else’s property.
Guest passenger liability, which pays for legal expenses of someone driving your boat with permission.
Medical payments, which pay expenses for you and your passengers.
Normal wear and tear.
Defective machinery or machinery damage.
Damage from sharks and other creatures.
Damage from mold, insects and zebra mussels.
Check, too, about additional coverage for trailers and accessories, for towing and for damage caused by an uninsured boater.
You can buy two types of damage coverage for a boat:
Actual cash value.
This pays the value of your boat at the time of the damage. If your boat is destroyed, your insurance company determines its market value.
Agreed amount value.
If your boat is destroyed, your insurer pays you an amount that you and the company agreed on beforehand. If your boat can be repaired, your insurer replaces old items for new ones without deducting for depreciation.
It’s also important to understand what your boat insurance covers before heading out on the water, says Todd Shasha, boat and yacht personal insurance director at Travelers Insurance. He recommends checking whether your policy can cover these scenarios:
Mechanical breakdown coverage.
Pays to repair or replace your outboard motor as long as it’s not due to wear and tear.
Salvage.
If your boat becomes disabled and a basic tow won’t help, you might need to call a salvage company to recover it. Typically a salvage company will ask for a percentage of the boat’s value as payment, which can be quite expensive. Not all insurance companies offer this coverage.
Gadgets.
Not all boat insurers cover expensive accessories like fishing equipment or fancy coolers unless they’re permanently attached to the boat. For example, Travelers offers personal property coverage that pays you if they’re stolen or lost while out on the water. Endorsements, which are additions to your policy, are available if you want to increase the value of your personal property limits.
Some important things to know about boating and your policy:
Navigational limits:
If you own a yacht or a larger boat, your policy will have limits outlining where you can navigate your vessel. If you venture outside of the territory you agreed to in the policy, your insurance may not cover you. Typically, the broader your navigation area is, the higher your insurance costs will be.
Layup periods:
Taking your boat out of the water is typical during cold weather, and most insurance companies will give you a credit because it’s not being used. But take the boat out for a spin before the layup period ends and you won’t be covered by your insurance policy.
Marine inspections:
If your boat is an older model, most insurance companies will want you to have it inspected by a marine surveyor in order to assess the vessel’s condition and market value. For safety’s sake, consider a marine survey even if it’s not required.
Underage operators:
You might be tempted to let your 12-year-old drive the boat every now and then. But if your child doesn't meet age and license requirements in your state, your boat insurance policy might not cover you.  Age and license requirements for operating personal watercraft vary from state to state. In Virginia and Florida, for example, no one under 14 may operate a personal watercraft. In Texas, children under 13 are barred from driving one unless a licensed operator who's at least 18 is on board. For requirements where you live, check with the boating regulatory agency in your state.
Boat insurance costs and discounts
How much you’ll pay for boat insurance depends on the level of insurance coverage you want, as well as the size, horsepower, type and value of your boat.
You can choose your deductible, which is the amount deducted from your insurance check if you make a claim. A typical policy has deductibles of $250 for property damage, $500 for theft and $1,000 for medical payments, according to the Insurance Information Institute. Liability claims against you do not have a deductible.
Insurance companies offer a variety of ways to save money, including discounts for:
Having a diesel-powered boat.
Not having made a previous boat insurance claim.
Carrying other policies, such as car or homeowners, with the same insurer.
Taking safety courses.
Where to buy boat insurance
Boat insurance is widely available. NerdWallet looked at the top 25 auto insurance sellers in the country and found these that also offer boat insurance:
AAA
Offers coverage for boats up to $250,000 in value.
AAA lowers your deductible by 25% each time you renew your policy and haven’t had a claim.
Allstate
Average cost of boat insurance from Allstate is about $20 a month, according to Allstate.
Bundle boat insurance with an Allstate homeowners policy and you qualify for up to a 20% discount.
American Family Insurance
Additional coverage options cover personal items and pay for repairs to your boat and equipment, without a deduction for depreciation.
Amica
If your boat is disabled, an Amica policy covers towing to nearest port.
If your yacht can’t be repaired, Amica pays to replace it with a new one, without subtracting depreciation.
Auto-Owners
Optional boat insurance coverage is available through homeowners policies.
Country Financial
Country Financial homeowners insurance covers your boat for up to $1,500.
You can buy more coverage under your homeowners policy.
Erie
Erie’s standard Boat Protector Policy comes with extras, including payments up to $500 to fix or replace boating equipment and accessories, and payments up to $250 for emergency towing. (Not available in Kentucky.)
Farmers
Farmers offers seven packages to fit your vessel type and coverage needs.
Geico
Geico’s optional premium boat towing service offers unlimited on-water towing (within 25 miles of an approved tower) and pays the service provider directly.
Geico offers several discounts, including one for passing a boat-safety course and for maintaining a good driving record.
Hanover
You can cover your boat, sailboat or personal watercraft with an endorsement to your Hanover Platinum or Connections homeowners insurance policy.
The Hartford
Additional coverage, which costs extra, is available for your accessories, trailer and boat hull.
Liberty Mutual
You must have a homeowners insurance policy with Liberty Mutual to get boat and watercraft insurance.
MetLife
Optional coverage includes hurricane protection, which pays up to $250 to move your boat out of danger during a hurricane advisory.
Unforeseen emergency services coverage pays $250 for towing and other services on land or in the water.
Nationwide
Personal watercraft coverage includes liability, collision, comprehensive, uninsured or underinsured operator, and medical payments.
Optional towing and labor also available.
Progressive
Total loss replacement coverage pays for a new boat if your new boat is a total loss within five years of adding the coverage.
Progressive offers several specialized coverage options, including 24-hour roadside assistance if your car breaks down while towing your boat.
Unlike some insurers, Progressive doesn’t require you to submit a navigation plan. Nor does it require an inspection of your boat.
State Farm
State Farm’s optional emergency service pays up to $500 to service your boat, motor or boat trailer.
Optional wreck-removal coverage pays “reasonable expenses” to raise or remove your boat when it’s required by law.
Travelers
Travelers splits the cost to move the vessel to safety when you carry “hurricane-escape reimbursement” coverage, which costs extra.
Antique boats get the same comprehensive coverage available in Travelers' basic policy.
USAA
USAA members get a 5% discount on boat insurance, but the discount is not available in all states.
USAA is open only to active and retired military and their families.
Juan Castillo is a former staff writer at NerdWallet.

Chase 5% Bonus Categories, Q1 2026: Dining, Norwegian Cruise Line, American Heart Association
Many or all of the products on this page are from partners who compensate us when you click to or take an action on their website, but this does not influence our evaluations or ratings. Our opinions are our own.

Ahead of the new year, Chase has announced its bonus categories for the first quarter of 2026.
From Jan. 1 through March 31, 2026, holders of the
Chase Freedom Flex®
and the legacy
Chase Freedom®
can earn 5% cash back on dining as well as some more niche categories — Norwegian Cruise Line and the American Heart Association.
Cardholders will earn the elevated rate on up to $1,500 in combined purchases across all three categories. All other non-bonus-category spending earns 1% back.
If you have an eligible Chase Freedom card, you must activate this quarter’s categories by March 14, 2026. You can earn rewards retroactively, as long as you activate by that deadline.
» MORE:
Bonus calendars for Chase, Discover and other 5% bonus cards
How this quarter’s bonus categories shake out
Dining
Chase Freedom Flex®
cardholders can earn up to 7% cash back on dining purchases for the first quarter of the new year. This includes the 3% back the card already earns on an ongoing basis for dining purchase, plus an additional 4% back from the quarter's bonus category.
Eligible purchases include dining in, but also takeout or delivery from eligible restaurants. Note that bakeries, caterers, meal kit delivery services and gift cards are not included in the category.
» MORE:
NerdWallet's best credit cards for restaurants
Norwegian Cruise Line
This highly specific travel category first appeared on Chase's bonus calendar in the first quarter of 2025, so this marks a return during the same period for 2026. Eligible purchases include those made directly with the cruise line, but not those made through third-party vendors or travel agencies.
» MORE:
NerdWallet's best credit cards for cruises
American Heart Association
Chase is extending the season of giving into the new year with a never-before-offered bonus category. Through March 31, 2026, eligible cardholders can earn bonus back for charitable donations made directly through the American Heart Association’s
official channels
. Be aware that local AHA chapters may not be eligible for the higher rate.
Chase has offered bonus rewards for “select charities” in the past, typically in the last quarter of the year. However, this is the first time this specific charity has appeared on the bonus calendar.
Here’s a closer look at what Chase offered in 2025:
Chase Freedom®
and
Chase Freedom Flex®
bonus rewards categories for 2026
Q1 (Jan. 1-March 31)
Restaurants
Norwegian Cruise Line.
American Heart Association.
Q2 (April 1-June 30)
TBD.
(In 2025: Amazon; select streaming services. June only: Eligible internet, cable and phone services.)
Q3 (July 1-Sept. 30)
TBD.
(In 2025: Gas/EV charging; live entertainment; Instacart.)
Q4 (Oct. 1-Dec. 31)
TBD.
(In 2025: Chase Travel℠; department stores; Old Navy. December only: PayPal.)
» MORE:
Which 5% rotating bonus category card should you choose?
Information related to the
Chase Freedom®
credit card has been collected by NerdWallet and has not been reviewed or provided by the issuer of this card.

American Airlines Cards Hike Bonuses, Up to 100,000 Miles
Many or all of the products on this page are from partners who compensate us when you click to or take an action on their website, but this does not influence our evaluations or ratings. Our opinions are our own.

As part of American Airlines' 100th anniversary celebration, several of the carrier's Citi-issued AAdvantage credit cards are increasing their welcome bonuses.
For a limited time, new holders of the following cards are eligible for 30,000 more bonus miles than previously offered:
Citi® / AAdvantage® Executive World Elite Mastercard®
: For a limited time, earn 100,000 American Airlines AAdvantage® bonus miles after spending $10,000 within the first 3 months of account opening.
Citi® / AAdvantage® Globe™ Mastercard®
: For a limited time, earn 90,000 American Airlines AAdvantage® bonus miles after $5,000 in purchases within the first 4 months of account opening.
Citi® / AAdvantage® Platinum Select® World Elite Mastercard®
: For a limited time, earn 80,000 bonus miles after $3,500 in purchases within the first 4 months of account opening.
» MORE:
American Airlines AAdvantage program: The complete guide
NerdWallet values
American miles at
1.3 cents
each. This is drawn from real-world data on hundreds of economy routes, so it's not a maximized value. In other words, you should aim for award redemptions that offer
1.3 cents
or more in value from your American miles.
Here’s how all the American Airlines credit cards stack up:
American Airlines AAdvantage® MileUp®
• 2 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent at grocery stores, including grocery delivery services, and on eligible American Airlines purchases.
• 1 AAdvantage mile per $1 spent on other purchases.
Citi® / AAdvantage® Platinum Select® World Elite Mastercard®
• 2 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent at gas stations and restaurants and on eligible American Airlines purchases.
• 1 AAdvantage mile per $1 spent on all other purchases.
• First checked bag free for cardholder and up to 4 traveling companions on the same reservation.
Citi® / AAdvantage® Globe™ Mastercard®
• 6 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent on eligible AAdvantage Hotels bookings.
• 3 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent on eligible American Airlines purchases.
• 2 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent at restaurants, including takeout and delivery.
• 1 AAdvantage mile per $1 spent on all other purchases.
• First checked bag free for cardholder and up to 8 traveling companions on the same reservation.
• One American Airlines companion certificate every card anniversary for a single round-trip qualifying domestic flight in main cabin. Redeemable for $99 plus taxes and fees.
• Limited Admirals Club access.
Citi® / AAdvantage® Executive World Elite Mastercard®
• 10 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent on eligible car rentals and hotels booked through American Airlines.
• 4 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent on eligible American Airlines purchases (5 miles per dollar after spending $150,000 in total on the card in a calendar year).
• 1 AAdvantage mile per $1 spent on all other purchases.
• First checked bag free for cardholder and up to 8 traveling companions on the same reservation.
• Admirals Club airport lounge membership and access for up to 2 guests or immediate family members traveling with the cardholder.
AAdvantage® Aviator® Red World Elite Mastercard®
• 2 AAdvantage miles per $1 spent on eligible American Airlines purchases.
• 1 AAdvantage mile per $1 spent on all other purchases.
• First checked bag free for cardholder and up to 4 traveling companions on the same reservation.
» MORE:
Best American Airlines credit cards
Information related to the
Citi® / AAdvantage® Platinum Select® World Elite Mastercard®
has been collected by NerdWallet and has not been reviewed or provided by the issuer of this card.
