Guide to Cruising Ithaca: Greek Charter Destinations
Charter skipper Tom Fletcher gives you a guided tour of his favourite Ionian island of Ithaca, home of the mythical hero Odysseus.
Author
:
Tom Fletcher
Published Date:
14 August 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Aerial view of the tranquil Kioni on the Greek Ionian island of Ithaca. Credit: Adobe Stock
Aerial view of the tranquil Kioni on the Greek Ionian island of Ithaca
Charter skipper Tom Fletcher gives you a guided tour of his favourite Ionian island of Ithaca, home of the mythical hero Odysseus.
Nestled in the sapphire
Ionian Sea
, Ithaca is my favourite island in the southern Ionian. Without an international airport, it remains untouched by mass tourism, preserving an authentic atmosphere. Woven into the fabric of Homeric legend is more than just the fabled home of Odysseus – Ithaca is a place where magic and reality are hard to separate. In summer, as the sun blazes overhead and cicadas fill the olive groves, time stands still in the anchorages.
As you sail around headlands, bay after bay appears, inviting you to drop anchor and never leave. Rocky hills with trails through pine forests to ancient ruins offer glimpses into a landscape that has inspired poets and adventurers for centuries. Ithaca offers some of the best anchorages and harbours in the Ionian.
The North
Approaching from Sail Ionian’s base on Lefkada, the first you see of legendary Ithaca is the rugged vertical cliffs of Afales Bay. While the water is such an inviting turquoise colour, we often caution charter guests about this area. There are some wonderful, secluded beaches, but underwater rocks lurk waiting to surprise unsuspecting charterers. The bay also offers no shelter once the predominant northwesterly winds start to blow, leaving a yacht on a rocky lee shore with swell coming in. On a calm morning, it can be a great place for a quick dip, but I rarely linger.
The Northeast
The stretch of coast from Afales in the north to Vathi in the south is probably the busiest section of Ithaca. It encompasses some lovely anchorages and the popular harbours of Frikes and Kioni. This area is known for its afternoon gusts and katabatic winds and the many ruined windmills on the headlands bear witness to this!
My first stop when coming from Lefkada is often in Marmagkas Bay. This sheltered beach is protected by reef around the tiny island chapel of St Nikolaos which guards the entrance and provides some of the best snorkelling on Ithaca. It can be very gusty on an afternoon here – long line from the beach to put your stern into the wind if you’re staying all day.
Frikes is the first port you will come to, and the bays along the entrance to the north and south make nice anchorages, though they can get busy with flotillas. Frikes itself, unfortunately, suffers from ferry swell, which builds as it enters the narrowing bay and can cause damage to yachts on the exposed quay. Most boats choose to raft up behind the breakwater on the southern side of the harbour. I’m not really a fan of this as you have people walking all over your yacht all night. The village itself is pleasant though, and there are some good restaurants on the quay.
It is Kioni, though, that is the jewel of the northeast coast. Possibly the most beautiful harbour in the Ionian with three ruined windmills guarding the entrance. I have a soft spot for Kioni despite its challenging mooring situation. The quayside is usually full by early afternoon, though getting there on a Monday should beat the flotillas. I always used to try to arrive around 5pm, just as the last tour boat was vacating a space. When timed right, you could avoid the mess of long-lined boats on the southern shore and moor stern-to on the outside of the mole. It’s deep and rocky where you drop, but I’ve never had an issue; you just need to be quick getting your first stern line on, as the wind is usually behind you blowing you off, and there isn’t much space.
Kioni seems to glow at golden hour, and as the sun sets, katabatic gusts funnel down the valley cooling the heat from the day. The village is stunning, and the pretty handmade jewellery shop in an old house is ideal for a sparkly souvenir and very popular with our guests. There are excellent dining options, including one restaurant in a building at the end of the quay that was built for Elizabeth Hamilton, niece of Lord Nelson! After dinner, don’t miss the quirky jazz bar for a late-night cocktail.
Greece ithaki island, panoramic view of the sea by the main harbor of ithaka island
Cruising Ithaca: Vathi
The entrance into Ithaca’s capital is long and fjord-like, with awesome steep hills. It makes for a beautiful view but can funnel a strong northwesterly into the harbour, and results in Vathi being untenable on occasional summer evenings.
Approaching the main town, you first pass a quay on the northeast shore. This is a sheltered location, a 5-10 minute walk from the town, and it is popular with the flotillas due to its lone taverna. Mooring here is the best bet when the northwest wind is strong.
Passing the Lazareto island, the large main town quay comes into view. Vathi is a busy little town, great for provisioning, and my favourite place to be when the wind blows from the south and brings rain in the shoulder season. In the peak summer months, it can be a little noisy, but the buzz of a town is fun after a string of quiet anchorages. Look for the quaint back street ‘Douriou Ippou’ with some nice boutiques and a really good restaurant on a corner. The promenade around the sea front is a pretty walk too, passing the Drakoulis mansion on the way to the small Archaeology Museum. Take a seat in the square in the early evening and enjoy watching the world go by, and, if you have youth on your side, the late-night bars on the eastern shore are worth a visit after dinner.
Cruising Ithaca: The Southeast
Once south of Vathi, the wind generally calms and afternoons can be long, still and hot, filled with the sound of cicadas. This stretch of coast has some amazing anchorages, and I always advise Sail Ionian’s guests to take some time and explore it.
Gidaki beach is the first anchorage you will see, a distinctive beach split in half by a landslide with inviting turquoise water and a beach bar. It’s a lovely swim stop after leaving Vathi, but tends to fill up in the afternoons and can get very busy.
Just south of Gidaki is Filatrou, which is one of my favourites. The bay has two sides, the southern beach with swimming buoys is backed by olive groves that hide a cool beach bar serving great food, while the northern cliff-backed beach is a beautiful anchorage.
Around the headland is hidden Sarakiniko, another pretty pebbly beach with lovely water fringed by olives trees hiding its own simple beach bar.
South again is Pera Pigadi, just that bit further than many charter yachts venture. The sea around this tiny island is often flat calm on an afternoon. There’s a 4m deep channel to anchor in, with more anchorages near the little beaches just to the south. Pera Pigadi has crystal-clear water and, in the hills above the bay, the Spring of Arethusa, mentioned in Homers ‘Iliad’. I often spend the night here and cook on board as it’s peaceful even in the peak summer months.
Rounding the south of Ithaca, the anchorages begin to peter out. The last one is Agios Andreou, a steep ravine and very deep, but it can be an attractive option if you want to get away from people.
Cruising Ithaca: The West
Anchorages are few and far between on the west coast, and there are no harbours to speak of except for the small ferry landing at Aetos where a boat comes from Kefalonia. There are some small coves which can be lovely for the brave long liner but nothing big enough to accommodate a few boats apart from Aetos Bay.
You must go all the way to the northwest to find Polis, facing Fiscardo. Many yachts long line on the northwest shore but, if you are just outside the swimming buoys, you can swing on the anchor in between 5-10m of water off the beach. The bay has a mysterious past – the name means ‘city’ in Greek – and, though there is no village here, there are ruins in the terraced olive trees west of the beach. Bronze Age golden sculptures were found in a cave on the north shore and an ancient chapel is half buried in the hillside near the fishing harbour. A 20-minute walk up the hill brings you to the village of Stavros, with its lovely square, tavernas, and exhibit about Odysseus. Sandy near the beach, but with thick weed in places, have a look in the water from the bow and drop in a lighter patch where you see sand. Polis is sheltered by steep hillsides all around and on a settled day the wind does lazy circles around the bay. Avoid if strong winds are forecast – the wind has a nasty habit of accelerating down the hillside and it can blow a hoolie if you’re here on the wrong night. I’ve had to leave in the middle of the night before and many friends have similar stories!
default
Walk 20 minutes up the hill for dinner in the village of Stavros. Trust me, it’s worth it for the pretty square and great grill house (there’s a hotel with a pool bar halfway up if you need a rest). In the centre of the village is a display and a reconstruction of the ruins of a Bronze Age palace complex found nearby. It is believed to have been Odysseus’ home and can be visited by taxi, though little remains to the untrained eye apart from some monumental stone foundations. Recent excavations have rekindled interest in this site and discovered evidence of pilgrimages and cult worship in antiquity, showing Odysseus’ enduring allure. If you go up to see the ruins of the Bronze Age complex, visit the nearby village of Exogi for lunch with a spectacular view over Afales Bay, as I’m sure Odysseus himself did.
Sailing around Ithaca offers a blend of beautiful harbour towns and secluded coves, making it a favourite among Ionian sailors seeking a relaxed pace. Many anchorages feature clear waters, scenic beaches, and easy access to traditional villages, but depths can be significant, often requiring substantial lengths of anchor chain, and early evenings can be windy, so caution is needed. The culture and history of the islands shines through, putting it at the top of the list to me.

Top 5 New Boats on the Market: Fresh Sailing Yacht Designs
Here’s our top picks from the latest yacht designs - what’s your favourite?
Author
:
Sam Jefferson
Published Date:
4 December 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
new boats - J7
Kraken 44
Kraken Yachts is the brainchild of businessman and sailor Dick Beaumont who, like so many before him, decided to build his dream boat and, off the back of that, launched a new sailing brand of blue water cruisers built to his own exacting vision of what a blue water cruiser should be. Unlike so many before him, Beaumont actually made it work and the result is a niche brand of highly innovative boats tailored for blue water cruising and designed by Kiwi Kevin Dibley. The 44 is the latest addition and the smallest boat in the range so far. She retains all the key features through including a centre cockpit set up, skeg hung rudder and innovative Z Keel bolting system which is viewed as pretty bulletproof. If you’re after a serious blue water cruiser, this could be the boat for you.
Kraken 44
krakenyachts.com
Windelo 62
French manufacturer Windelo has carved a niche for itself by producing fast cruising catamarans that offer a high level of sustainability due to innovative basalt construction married to electric hybrid motor set ups and sustainably sourced materials for decking and interior fit out. The company has flourished since its launch in 2016 and their new 62 is a sign of the ambition of the boatbuilder. This is their biggest yacht to date and it has the same sustainable features as the smaller boats just on a larger scale. This is definitely a performance cruiser, featuring daggerboards and a powerful rig, but the boat is also set up to be sailed easily by a couple – although understandably given the size of this boat, there is a skipper’s cabin. The interior design by Stellantis also looks suitably slick.
Windelo 62
windelo-catamaran.com
Divinite 7m
The Divinite 7 is the brainchild of Eric Henseval, a naval architect who has conceived the boat as a fast cruiser/expedition boat that can be home built. According to Henseval, there are already two models being built in Europe. Ease of construction is key and the epoxy/ply is the favoured materiel, although it could also be built in either GRP or aluminium. The boat features a relatively powerful rig and twin rudders married to a twin lifting keel set u that would allow the boat to dry out in shallow harbours. The full scow bow boosts internal volume to make the boat more comfortable than you’d expect a 21’ yacht to be.
hensevalyachtdesign.jimdofree.com
Divinite 7m
J Boats J/7
What seems like many centuries ago, J Boats built the first J/24 and, in doing so, the company hit the big time. Back then performance day sailers were big business. It’s not so much the case these days, with most boatbuilders shying away from building uncomplicated entry level yachts like this, so hats off to J Boats for going back to their roots with the J/7. The boat is clearly going to be quite quick but is also easy to handle and features a big cockpit with a small enclosed ‘cabin’ forward which is exclusively for storage unless you are a true masochist. The boat has a generous sail area but a deep keel and decent beam suggest a stiff boat that is fun and easy to handle.
J Boats J/7
Jboats.com
Y Yachts Y6
Boatbuilder and general maverick Michael Schmidt is best known for setting up Hanse Yachts back in the day but, once he sold off that business, he found himself at a loose and and set up Y Yachts, a luxury boatbuilder specialising in lightweight, carbon fibre semi custom semi-superyachts. The Y6 is of more interest to us because this is the smallest boat in the range so far at 64’, opening the market out to a far broader audience. This Bill Tripp design retains the sleek lines and uncluttered decks of its larger sisters and the blend of luxury and performance makes this an intriguing proposition. Y Yachts maintain that this is a boat that is easily handled by a small crew and a full time skipper is not necessary.
Y Yachts Y6
yyachts.de

How a Professional Mariner Met the World of Cruising
Never in his wildest dreams did Paul imagine himself on a fare-paying cruise contemplating the onboard activities!
Author
:
Paul Heiney
Published Date:
26 November 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
cruising  |  Photo credit: Shutterstock
I was at a dinner with like-minded cruising people. Conversations, as usual, started off on a fairly high plane of adventure on the high seas, but quickly descended into wailing over marina prices, cost of diesel, harbour master grumbles, and anything else which breathes a whiff of sadness into the souls of anyone who owns a boat. So, hoping for more uplifting conversation I turned to the woman on my right and said, “I go cruising, what do you do?” Such a banal question I hoped she might change places. What she came back with nearly had me off my seat.
“I ADORE cruising,” she declared. “Oh, it’s such a GORGEOUS experience.” I’ve heard it described many ways but never quite as enthusiastically as that, often quite the reverse. But here was a woman so taken with our sport that she looked as though she was about to break into an operatic appreciation. The prospects for the rest of the evening rose dramatically.
It was about 15 minutes later that I managed to piece together a rather perplexing jigsaw, for she had indeed made some noteworthy voyages with talk of Pacific anchorages, ocean crossings as well as a bit a bit of high latitudes stuff, even though she wasn’t at all worried about the price of diesel.
You will have guessed by now that her vessel of choice was over a thousand tons with a dozen restaurants and not a hand-pumped lavatory in sight. Once I made it clear there was nobody on my vessel to turn down my bed, or leave a chocolate mint on the pillow, we had a laugh.
And where do I find myself right now? On a
cruise ship
. Me! After all these years of somewhat despising them. However, I have chosen a four-masted barquentine where crew do the hard work and I enjoy three hot meals a day and none of them out of a Fray Bentos tin, so I haven’t completely swallowed my principles. It is still sailing, as well as quite a learning experience.
Take the first thing that happened after we’d stepped aboard – the
safety
briefing. There were three of them; one now, another in a couple of hours time, and a further one the following morning in case we’d forgotten the first two. I realised to my shame that I have become woefully inadequate when it comes to these important matters. Certainly I make sure everyone has
lifejacket
and wears it, but by the time I tell my crew where the flares are I am fast running out of steam. ‘The flares are in a yellow canister in the aft locker,’ I will intone in great seriousness, before being interrupted by a cry from below, ‘No! We moved them to the ropes locker, to make room for….’ ‘But I moved them back’ I declare as I fling open the locker before closing it quickly when it appears I haven’t moved them back at all.
I was once moored next to a decent sized charter boat where the skipper elevated the safety briefing to new heights. His customers arrived in the afternoon, one by one. Introductions took place, somewhat uncomfortably, and then he launched into his epic speech on safety. I went below, had something to eat, did a bit of route planning, read the newspaper, and came up to find him still at it an hour and a half later, his fare-paying customers sitting with a glazed looks in their eyes wondering why they ever signed up to this punishment. I later learned that the skipper had retired from safety officer duties on North Sea oil rigs and this was his new career and thoroughness was his religion. I also learned later that his unique selling point was that his cruises were targeted at ‘Singles’ – solo travellers, some of them seeking romance. If there was anything better designed to dampen a romantic atmosphere, it was his fifteen minute lecture on ‘avoiding burns’. I didn’t see the look of newly-found love flickering across any faces as they trudged ashore, in complete safety of course.
Looking for further inspiration as to what might improve my own crew’s experience and get me some of those highly valued stars on Trustpilot, I glanced down the list of offered activities on the ship I was on. Should I opt for Water Gymnastics with Samuel or cocktail mixing on the Tropical Deck? Guess.
And then I found Walk a Mile with a Smile. You stagger round the ship as many times as it takes to clock up a mile. I’ve done a calculation. On my boat, at 40ft long, one circuit takes 80ft which is 0.015 of a mile. That means 70 circuits grinning as you go! No stopping for romance. though.

Caribbean Charter Holiday Guide: Finding the Best Winter Sailing Destination
The seemingly endless British summer helped ease the transition into autumn, but with winter’s harsh grip soon to arrive, now is the perfect time to plan your great escape – why not sign up for a Caribbean charter holiday, says Sue Pelling?
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
8 October 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Caribbean Charter Holiday  |  Photo credit: Shutterstock
Winter sun sailing in the Caribbean has become a top choice for yacht charter enthusiasts thanks to its reliable climate, which generally offers steady trade winds, warm tropical temperatures, and some of the world’s most breathtaking cruising grounds. The ideal time to visit is between December and April, which is comfortably outside the hurricane season.
Thanks to the Caribbean’s popularity for on-the-water holidays, it is home to a wide variety of charter options, including flotilla adventures, skippered, and bareboat charters. Companies like Nautilus which covers destinations such as British Virgin Islands (BVIs), Antigua, Grenada and St Vincent, St Lucia, Martinique, St Martin, Guadeloupe, Bahamas, Belize, also offer last minute bookings, which is a good incentive if you have the opportunity to just ‘book and go’.
Caribbean Charter Holiday Guide  |  Photo credit: Shutterstock
Jonathan Shears – Managing Director at
Nautilus
– was keen to offer a few booking tips: “While we offer last minute bookings, the majority of Caribbean bookings come in 11 months before departure which coincides with the flights being released. If you are not fixed to school holidays then a sweet spot is the month of January when the weather and winds are great but the availability and prices are good.”
Like Nautilus,
Plain Sailing
’s Co-Founder Adi Tognarelli, says bookings in this part of the world are on the rise: “The Caribbean season already looks to be one of the biggest, with record numbers of new catamarans out on the waters around our bases – from Antigua and Barbuda through to the BVI, Bahamas and the Grenadines.”
Commenting on the types of charter that are particularly popular, Tognarelli added: “We’re seeing increased interest for more ‘off-the-beaten’ track destinations like Gaudeloupe and Martinique, which can be difficult to get to but sailors are rewarded with perfect sailing conditions, wall-to-wall sunshine, and some incredible views.”
And the popular holiday periods? Tognarelli concluded: “Christmas and New Year continue to dominate, with many of our charter partners already fully booked, even at the incredibly expensive peak-peak prices. Look for charters in April and May for the best bang for your buck – still great conditions for sailing in.”
The other main reason the Caribbean has grown in popularity over the past couple of decades is its relative ease of access. Islands like Antigua, Grenada, and St Lucia are served by regular non-stop flights from the UK, typically taking just 8 to 10 hours. Even destinations that require a connection, such as the British Virgin Islands, US Virgin Islands, or St Martin, are still reachable within a total travel time of around 12 to 14 hours.
Caribbean charter  |  Photo credit: Sunsail
Sunsail
, which operates from a selection of bases in the Caribbean including the British Virgin Islands, St Lucia, Grenada, Antigua, Bahamas, Belize, St Martin, and Martinique is a popular choice for charter. Like most other companies, Sunsail’s UK/ZA/AU Marketing Manager Caroline Barbour says the Caribbean is the go-to winter charter with customers booking well in advance: “This winter, we’ve seen an increase in bookings, largely due to shifting customer behaviour over the past year. Unlike the typical shorter booking window, many clients are now securing their charters further in advance. We attribute this to a strong volume of repeat bookings, with guests eager to reserve their preferred yachts early to avoid disappointment. Additionally, the continued resurgence of the BVIs following Hurricane Irma has contributed to steady growth in demand for this destination in particular.”
Most companies offer a choice of charter options with bareboat chartering remaining popular, especially for families and groups who want the freedom to sail independently. For those with less experience – or without the required skipper qualifications – a skippered charter (with a qualified skipper onboard) is a great alternative, offering a stress-free holiday with the added bonus of learning the ropes from a professional at sea.
For solo travellers, couples, or friends seeking the freedom of the open ocean and the excitement of a sailing holiday without the responsibility of being in charge of the yacht, ‘By the Cabin’ charters offer the perfect solution. Available in certain destinations from companies like Sunsail,
The Moorings
, and
Dream Yacht Charter
, these trips let you enjoy all the fun of a charter experience but with a professional crew at the helm.
Other companies including yacht charter agents like
SamBoat
, or
Anchor.yt
operate across many Caribbean regions, for sailors of all levels of experience. There are also numerous other companies out there however, including bespoke, luxury charters from specialist companies like
Inter Yacht
, and
The Globe Sailor
, which may be worth considering.
Finally, the best way to keep abreast of latest offers is to keep an eye on your preferred company website (see Useful contact list below). Ideally, make contact with the company and relay your holiday requirements because most are happy to help tailor your needs to ensure you experience that dream sailing holiday in the sun.

Yachts for Sale: Three of the Best Sailing Boats on the Market
Here’s our top picks from the yacht market - some beautiful sailing boats ready for their next chapter.
Author
:
Sailing Today
Published Date:
24 November 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
yachts for sale  |  Photo credit: Alex Grabu
RUSTLER 44 |  SEA HAYES
Designed by Stephen Jones to produce a swift, comfortable passage, and built by Rustler Yachts for stunning, durable living, this is an ultimate bluewater cruising yacht. She has recently returned to the UK following a season in the Caribbean, and is a fine example offered in ready to sail condition with many features including a generator, inverter, heating, bow thruster, electric halyard winch, and electric primary winches.
Sea Hayes
also has a comprehensive electronics package, davits, white sails (2020), cruising chute, recent batteries, recent standing rigging, dinghy and outboard, and much more. She is in very good condition and is currently located outside the Rustler factory in Falmouth.
yachts for sale - Rustler 44  |  Photo credit: Red Ensign

2011

13.50m (44’5")

yachts for sale - Rustler 44  |  Photo credit: Red Ensign

red-ensign.com
Yachts for Sale: Catamaran
GUNBOAT 48 | DANCING BEAR
Dancing Bear
is an extremely rare to the market Morrelli & Melvin-designed carbonfibre Gunboat 48 with upgraded rig and interior. She has had just one private owner since new and is now offered for sale with a great performance-cruising inventory. She has been finished to a high standard including a new interior by Riskas Snickeri (Nautor Swan & Baltic Yachts) which the broker reports costing circa €600,000 in 2013. She also has many inventory highlights including 3-cabin, 3-heads interior layout with a sumptuous owner’s cabin aft, and VIP cabins forward. Her windows and all glass were renewed in 2019 and, in 2010 she had a new rig and taller wing-mast fitted by Marström, as well as new ECSix standing rigging in 2022. Her sail wardrobe comprises, Harken low-friction battencars for fully-battened mainsail, North 3Di mainsail and jibs (2011), One Sails mainsail and J2 (2023), new unused code zero from North Sails, plus a furling code zero and spinnakers. Navigation wise,
Dancing Bear
is fully equipped for serious cruising including a B&G navigation system with plotter, HD radar, AIS and night-vision top-mast camera, as well as twin autopilot systems.
yachts for sale - Gunboat 48  |  Photo credit: Alex Grabu

MOODY DS 41 |  VENTURA
Ventura
is the first of the sought-after Moody DS 41s to come up for sale in the UK and is a very good, highly specified example with only 155 hours on the clock. She was launched and commissioned for the 2022 season and the brokers report that she is ‘nicely presented for sale’. This particular Moody – also known as the Moody 41 DS and Moody Deck saloon 41 – is the shallow draft keel version, and has plenty of features including twin forestay upgrade, electric winches, full Raymarine navigation suite, heating system, electric loo and more. She has a Selden rig with an electric in-mast furling system, furlex inner forestay (manual), furlex outer forestay (electric), manual backstay adjuster, and a rodkicker/vang. Her sail wardrobe comprises Elvstrom bluewater dacron in-mast furling mainsail, self-tacking jib, and 140% genoa.

Learning to Sail the Hard Way: Paul Heiney’s Advice for Beginners
Learning the hard way is sometimes the best way says Paul as he recalls his early sailing experiences!
Author
:
Paul Heiney
Published Date:
7 January 2026
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
I have always been an admirer of that great voyager and mountaineer, Bill Tilman. He took to sailing late in life and used it as a vehicle to sail to parts of the world where there were unclimbed peaks to conquer. He was one tough guy; hardended by experience in the Word War I trenches. He viewed with scorn crew who would not eat sardine spines and, worst of all, men who insisited on wearing gloves at sea in the north Atlantic in the summer. You didn’t sign up with Tilman for a dream cruise.
One remark always sticks in my mind. He was often asked “how do I get to go on an expedition”, to which his stark reply was, “you put on your boots and go”.
Unhelpful, perhaps, but it is exactly how I learnt how to sail. Wanting to go to sea but having nobody to turn to for advice, I bought myself a 17ft boat up a river in Essex and started to figure it. I went to evening classes to learn how to read a chart and figure the tides but as far as the actual sailing went, I had to figure that out for myself, mostly by trial and error, and plenty of error. But I learnt, slowly. Eventually I took off, alone, across the North Sea. In true Tilman fashion, I just pulled on my (then) yellow wellies and went. Although I say it myself, I haven’t done too badly since. Which is why when newcomers to sailing turn to me for advice, I offer them two options – find yourself a sailing school, or get those boots on and learn sailing the hard but most rewarding way.
But I broke my rule recently and did offer advice to a friend who, fairly late in life, has taken to the water. His boat was also on an east coast river and he wanted to make an ambitious passage north through the Wallet – a stretch of water I have never found to be in a pleasant mood – then to Harwich and beyond. I remembered this run well from my early days and so advised him of where to
anchor
to wait out a tide, and warned against trying to get into marinas unless he was certain he could drive his feeble-engined craft safely into a berth. Which is why my strongest recommendation was to make full use of his anchor. The
east coast
rivers are built for anchoring; you can find shelter from most winds and with a plentiful supply of adhesive mud which grips an anchor like a dog’s mouth on a bone, you can stop, take a pause, put the kettle on and listen to the curlews and move on when the tide serves.
I heard back from him some weeks later. It didn’t go well. His carefully worked out plan fell apart with headwinds in the Wallet and darkness falling as the tide turned against him. I asked him if my advice on anchorages was any use and he replied, rather meekly, “I didn’t know how to use the anchor.” It was very tempting to think less of a chap who has failed to come to grips with one of the fundamental ‘get your out of trouble’ bits of kit, but the anchor remained a mystery to him.
But then I cast my mind back. I remember leaving Brightlingsea, working the tide to the mouth of the Colne, then catching the new flood to take me northwards. Oh, the sheer excitement at seeing the lights of Clacton appearing above the horizon. This was real voyaging.
And then the greatest challenge (which remains to this day) was spotting the diminutive Pye End buoy against the Dovercourt coastline. Much anxiety, then into the Walton Backwaters to drop the anchor in that lovely spot just inside Stone Point. Drifting along, the air was thick with seabirds, grazing horses along the river banks. This was heaven.
And then I dropped anchor – my first time. The chain rattled but, suspiciously, not for very long. Had I bothered to get it out of its locker before setting off I would have realised that the chain was all of two metres long with a dodgy length of rope attached. I did manage to lengthen it, thanking the Gods for a calm night, since the only other bit of rope on board appeared to have the strength of parcel string.
So there we are; two raw beginners nearly 50 years apart making the same stupid mistake. There are some lessons which can only be learnt to hard way, and I reckon my friend probably learnt a few on his adventure. It might be that putting on your boots and getting on with it, is the best teacher of all.

Premier Falmouth Marina: Guide and Cruising Grounds
The Premier Falmouth Marina is Picturesque, well appointed, and conveniently positioned for serious west country cruising and beyond...
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
18 August 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
The marina is sheltered and well appointed. Credit: Premier Marinas
As far as locations go, the Premier Falmouth Marina is one of the most picturesque you’ll find. It is also well appointed, and conveniently positioned for serious west country cruising and beyond, says Sue Pelling.
50° 09’90N, 005°05’02W
The vibrant and historic town of Falmouth in Cornwall, which is located within an area of outstanding natural beauty is one of the most desirable places to visit when cruising the west country. Given its popularity there are plenty of sheltered berthing options available including Premier’s Falmouth Marina, which sits conveniently on the south bank up Penryn River.
The main Falmouth harbour, as you enter from the Channel – Carrick Roads – is one of the world’s largest natural deep-water harbours and extends northwards as far as the River Fal. In the 18th century it became a bustling hub for packet ships carrying mail, and other commercial goods including  timber, iron, coal, and charcoal. It was also an important harbour for the arrival of imported goods such as tea, spices and silks. Falmouth’s defence role in both world wars was crucial too because it served as a base for anti-submarine operations as well as an embarkation point for the D-Day landings.
Falmouth’s rich maritime heritage continues to be celebrated to this day with events such as the Falmouth Regatta,
Falmouth Classics
, the Oyster Festival, and the Falmouth International Sea Shanty Festival taking place every year. Falmouth Marina is within easy walking distance to the main hub which is home to a vast array of independent shops, restaurants and attractions such as Discovery Quay, the National Maritime Museum, and Pendennis Castle.
When you arrive at the marina you can be sure of a warm welcome by Premier’s staff who are on hand 24-hours a day to assist you with your berthing, and any help you require with facilities. As with all Premier Marinas, Falmouth Marina is well designed and laid out for ease of use. It has two berthing areas, with space for boats up to 18m loa on its outer pontoons, and up to 15m loa in its inner basin. For convenience it has a chandlery and restaurant (UpperDeck), and fuel bay for diesel onsite, and has a full-service boatyard as well as a range of businesses including a sailmaker, marine electronic specialist, a rigger, and a yacht broker.
Annual berth holders can also benefit from Premier Advantage, which offers a package of rewards, benefits and cost savings including 42 free visitor nights and unlimited short stays at any Premier marina, Sea Start benefits and savings, fuel at cost, special deals on insurance, and up to eight.
Passage Planning
The marina’s location on the south bank of the Penryn River (the first creek you see on the western side of the Fal Estuary) offers easy access but if your boat has a draft of 1.7m, avoid making the approach within 1.5 hours of low water springs. The channel is buoyed and the general approach to the marina is straightforward but it is, however, advisable to consult up-to-date charts, and check notes to mariners at the time of arrival in case of any changes.
The access channel is to the southwest of the east cardinal mark. Travel upstream, leaving Greenbank Quay to port. You will see the marina as you pass Boyers Cellars – a deep-water commercial jetty. Steer close to the marina’s outer pontoons, keeping between them and the east cardinal beacon, which shows the edge of the dredged area.
When you arrive, moor at the visitors’ hammerhead pontoon and call up reception on VHF Ch80 or using the pontoon telephone for berth allocation.
It is also worth noting the marina is divided in two by a cill that is marked at each end by a tide gauge. The cill dries to 1.8m above Chart Datum and visitors should only enter the inner basin after being given the go-ahead by marina staff. Finally, if you are a visitor, Premier says it strongly advises pre-booking, especially in peak season because it gives priority access to Premier berth holders visiting from other marinas.
Cruising Grounds
Once in the Fal estuary and you base yourself at the marina, you have 12nm of cruising options, stretching as far as the cathedral city of Truro, to explore. With beautiful wooded shorelines and plenty of creeks and places of interest to visit along the way, there’s hardly any need to go anywhere else. Take a sail round to Trelissick for example, where you can anchor off and visit the National Trust Trelissick house and gardens and enjoy the spectacular views. If you are intending to venture further afield to places like the Isles of Scilly, which is approximately 60nm away, or across the Channel, it’s an ideal safe, sheltered base. There are plenty of popular shorter passages on the ‘doorstep’ too including (to the east) the pretty town of Fowey just 20nm away, Plymouth 38nm away, or Salcombe in Devon 50nm. One of the most delightful places just south around the headland is the Helford River. This is a gem of a place to explore because it’s off the beaten track and offers stunning scenery, plenty of interesting anchorages, and attractive beaches particularly on the north shore of the Helford estuary.
Further afield, Jersey and the Channel Islands are logical destinations.

How to Go Racing in the Caribbean: Chartering for All Skill Levels
Whether you’re a seasoned sailor or a curious novice, racing in the Caribbean is what dreams are made of, offering charter options for all skill levels writes Sue Pelling
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
9 September 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
LV Yachting, RORC, Caribbean 600 race start  |  Photo credit: Alex Turnbull
Race charter in the Caribbean is not only all about sailing in turquoise waters with consistent trade winds and dramatic island backdrops but it’s also about being part of a lively, local tradition. You’ll find that many Caribbean islands that run regattas are major social and cultural events, blending sport, music, food, and island spirit. This cocktail of hard core, adrenaline-driven racing, and legendary rum punch-fuelled après-race parties are what Caribbean regattas are all about because above all they foster unforgettable memories and friendships that will probably last a lifetime.
The main Caribbean race season runs from January to late April, which not only avoids the hurricane season, but also gives overseas visitors plenty of time to make their trip south worthwhile, with many, particularly pro teams, using the Caribbean circuit as an ideal shake down to the forthcoming northern hemisphere race season.
Caribbean race charter  |  Photo credit: Gabe Rovick
There is a packed calendar of regattas to choose from and, thanks to the Caribbean Sailing Association (
CSA
), which promotes each event with its own identity, dates rarely clash, which means you could realistically take part in the whole Caribbean race series.
If however, holiday time is limited, you may want to return to your favourite haunt with events like
St Maarten Heineken Regatta
, the
BVI Spring Regatta & Sailing Festival
, or
Antigua Sailing Week
some of the most popular. For something different, yet equally fun and extremely competitive, maybe consider St Thomas International Regatta or St Barths Bucket.
Given its popularity, there’s a good choice of race yacht charter companies serving the Caribbean and covering events and feeder race/cruises such as the
World Cruising Club Atlantic Rally for Cruisers
(ARC and ARC+) an event which sets off across the Atlantic from Gran Canaria to the Caribbean mid to late November. This means there are many opportunities to sign up for a berth on either a private charter yacht, or charter yacht through companies such as LV Yachting, Go West Sailing, or Firstaway Yacht Charter.
While many companies offer crewed or bareboat charter options, a growing sector is individual berth charter. Sea to Sky Sailing primarily offers individual berth race charter opportunities aboard its race optimised Salona 45,
Panacea X
. Katy Campbell (Sea to Sky Sailing Director and lead race skipper) commented: “We are a frequent feature of the podium across the whole Caribbean circuit, and in 2025 were awarded the Traveler’s Trophy for being the top performing boat of the year. We are usually the only female-skippered boat on the circuit, often the only one flying the maple leaf, and one of the few associated with an RYA training centre.
Antigua English Harbour, Nelson's Dockyard  |  Photo credit: Shutterstock
“For the 2025/2026 Caribbean season, we will be racing in St Lucia’s Mango Bowl, Barbados Sailing Week, Rum to Spice Offshore Race, Grenada Sailing Week, RORC Caribbean 600, St Maarten Heineken Regatta, BVI Regatta and Antigua Sailing Week. We’re looking forward to another great season and look forward to having many familiar faces back on board as well as new crew joining us from all over the world.”
Another popular company is LV Yachting which specialises in race yacht charters across the Caribbean, and is passionate about connecting teams with high-performance yachts – from Volvo Ocean 65s and ORC winners to multihulls and top-tier racer cruisers. LV’s Chris Bruty commenting on what’s on offer said: “We offer whole-boat and crewed charters for events including the RORC Caribbean 600, Heineken Regatta, BVI Spring Regatta, Antigua Sailing Week and more. With 15+ years’ experience, we tailor every charter to the crew’s needs, handling logistics like berthing, race entry, and concierge support. Whether you’re a seasoned campaigner or new to Caribbean regattas, our personalised service ensures a competitive, seamless and unforgettable racing experience.”
As well as being one of the key cruising charter companies, Sunsail also offers a range of race charter options in the Caribbean. Caroline Barbour, Sunsail’s Marketing Manager UK/ZA/AU said: “Our team of expert holiday planners can offer advice on chartering a bareboat or skippered yacht, suitable for seasoned crews and those new to racing. The key events for next season include the BVI Spring Regatta, Antigua Sailing Week, Grenada Sailing Week, and the St Maarten Heineken Regatta.
“Customers benefit from the maintained charter fleet and access to Sunsail’s experienced skippers. It’s an excellent way to gain race entry, shore-side support, and seamless participation in top-tier Caribbean regattas. Off the water, racers enjoy legendary socials, island hospitality, and an unbeatable party atmosphere that comes with every regatta.”
Second Star Sailing, which participates in events such as Grenada Sailing Week, RORC 600 Caribbean, St Maarten Heineken Regatta, and St Barths Bucket also specialises in women’s sailing, and is particularly keen to promote its Women at the Helm in the Caribbean. Second Star Sailing’s Aliya Brown commenting on this popular programme said: “Through our all-women race team programme, Women at the Helm, Second Star Sailing is happy to support women in competitive sailing. Our two-week package is meant to give female sailors more confidence and skills.
“It includes a full week of race training skills to support passionate women in developing their skills in any role on a racing team, whether they are helm, trimmer, bow, or tactician. During the second week, we will be on the water for Antigua Sailing Week, racing with a crew that is excited to share their knowledge. Based in Antigua, we are dedicated to getting more women involved in racing by giving them access, mentoring, and world-class training in a lively regatta setting.”
Finally it’s worth remembering that access to the Caribbean with direct flights from the UK to many islands makes chartering a yacht a good option particularly if leisure time is more restricted. If you are flexible with time, you may be able to find some good last-minute deals, so it’s worth keeping an eye out online (see Useful contacts below).

What Is the Secret to Sunsail’s Success?
Sam Jefferson caught up with Sunsail’s Clive Norton to find out this charter industry global leader’s secrets of success.
Author
:
Sam Jefferson
Published Date:
5 August 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Croatia – a popular Sunsail destination  |  Photo credit: Sunsail
Sunsail is a charter industry global leader and has plenty to celebrate. Sam Jefferson caught up with Sunsail’s Clive Norton to find out the company’s secrets of success
.
Last year, Sunsail celebrated an incredible milestone – its 50th anniversary. A half-century of helping adventure-lovers explore the world from the deck of an award-winning yacht is no mean feat. Such an achievement can only be accredited to the consistent vision that has guided the company over the decades, with each generation of leadership united by a clear goal – to deliver unforgettable sailing experiences for the sailing community and beyond. To mark the occasion, we caught up with Clive Norton, VP of Revenue Management and Fleet Planning at Sunsail, to reflect on the company’s roots, discussing the journey from launching a small fleet in the Saronic Gulf to becoming a world leading sailing holiday company. In this exclusive interview, we delve into Sunsail’s origins, its milestones and where it is heading next.
Sunsail Vounaki Greece May 2010
Tell us about the history of Sunsail. How did it all begin?
“Sunsail was founded in 1974 and began with the simple ambition to make sailing fun, accessible, and social for everyone. Our very first base was in Aegina, in the stunning Saronic Gulf of Greece, which we still sail from today. We started with just seven 25ft Snapdragon monohulls in the first flotilla. They were sturdy yachts known for their twin bilge keels, shallow draft and spacious interiors – perfect for exploring coastal waters, with ample space in the galley to cater for a family while offering relative comfort. It was a modest start, but one rooted in a deep passion for the sea.
“The team back then was small but mighty. Skipper Janet Green led the first voyages with her Australian hostie, Megan, and English engineer David Archer. Unfortunately, we don’t know much about their history before Sunsail, but we do know that Janet’s role was particularly groundbreaking for the time. In 1974, it was quite rare – and often challenging – for a woman to hold a lead skipper position in the sailing world, which was then overwhelmingly male-dominated. Janet’s leadership not only showcased her exceptional skills and determination but also set an early example of inclusivity and progressiveness that Sunsail continues to embody today.
“This spirit of representation and breaking boundaries set by Janet and the team has continued to shape decision-making within the business. It’s no coincidence that Dee Caffari is one of Sunsail’s contemporary ambassadors. Dee made history as the first woman to sail solo, non-stop, around the world in both directions, and she remains one of the most respected figures in the sport. Her achievements resonate deeply with the values set by the founding team.
“Needless to say, the first ever flotilla trip was a great success, reaching beyond the expectations of the team, and went on to create the first market for holiday flotillas.”
How has Sunsail evolved over the years?
“Over the last five decades, we’ve come a long way. From those first flotilla holidays in Greece, we expanded across the Mediterranean, then into the Caribbean, and now offer bareboat charters in over 20 of the world’s most spectacular sailing destinations. Our flotilla sailing holidays now run in three countries, and our fleet has grown from seven Snapdragons to over 340 yachts.
“Throughout our journey, we’ve worked closely with iconic yacht manufacturers like Beneteau, Jeanneau, and Robertson & Caine to ensure our boats balance performance, comfort and sociability for our guests. Since the first flotilla in 1974 we have steadily invested in the fleet. By the late 1980s we had already added 120 new yachts to the Mediterranean. In 1993, we were operating 390 yachts across the Mediterranean and 100 in the Caribbean. In 2002, we placed a landmark £13 million order for 180 new yachts from Jeanneau, Beneteau, Fountaine Pajot, and Lagoon, further strengthening our global offering.
“Fleet renewal and expansion continued into the 2010s, with major additions from Robertson & Caine’s catamaran range and upgrades to our monohull fleet to match evolving guest expectations. In 2016, we introduced the Sunsail 454 – a custom-built catamaran designed specifically for the charter market. In 2020, we launched the Sunsail 41.0, a sleek, modern yacht created in collaboration with Jeanneau. Most recently, in 2023 and 2024, we continued our fleet growth through a partnership with Dufour, investing in models such as the Sunsail 37.3 and Sunsail 41.3., reflecting our growing focus on sustainability and innovation. Each phase of fleet growth has furthered our commitment to staying ahead of industry trends and delivering exceptional sailing experiences for every type of sailor.
“As we have grown the fleet, we have also deepened our offering to our community, which has seen our team pioneering experiences that accompany sailors through their entire journey. In 1986, we launched our first Beach Club to offer beginner-friendly holiday packages combining land and water-based activities. This marked the beginning of a series of Beach Clubs that followed across the Mediterranean and beyond. This period of time marked the opening of a new space in the market, where sailing enthusiasts could not only enjoy a holiday, but also earn their first sailing qualifications.
“By the mid-2010s our strategy evolved and moved towards a direction more closely reflecting the business we operate today – focusing on accessibility through our
RYA
-accredited Sailing Schools. From there, guests could progress to flotillas and eventually set off on their own bareboat adventures.”
What do you think has been the secret behind Sunsail’s success?
“Honestly, it’s that Sunsail has always been run by sailors, for sailors. We understand what makes a sailing holiday special because we live and breathe it ourselves. Our goal has never changed – we want to make sailing fun, inclusive, and accessible to all.
“And we’re passionate – deeply passionate – about what we do, and how we do it. That enthusiasm translates into everything from how we design our itineraries to how our teams interact with guests. It’s about creating unforgettable experiences and lifelong memories on the water.”
Sunsail Vounaki Greece May 2010
What are some of the most memorable highlights over the last 50 years?
“There are so many. Launching our Caribbean bases was a big step, bringing the Sunsail experience to turquoise waters and island cultures. Another huge moment was expanding our fleet beyond the Mediterranean and adding yachts from world-renowned manufacturers.
“But I think the most rewarding moments are the ones we hear from our guests – families who return year after year, couples who met on a flotilla and now bring their children back, or sailors who took their first lessons with us and are now skippering charters around the world. Those personal stories are what really define our legacy.”
What makes Sunsail unique today?
“Today, our guests have more choice than ever before. Looking for a self-guided adventure? Our bareboat charters offer the freedom to explore at your own pace – and in some locations, we’re even introducing off-grid itineraries for a more remote experience. Prefer a little more structure and camaraderie? Our flotillas provide a sociable and supportive way to sail, with the added reassurance of a lead crew always close by. And if you’re new to sailing, no problem – our RYA-accredited sailing schools are designed to help you learn while on holiday.
“We’ve hand-picked our destinations for their beauty and variety in sailing conditions – from the gentle breezes of the Ionian to the steady trade winds of the British Virgin Islands. It’s all about catering to every level of sailor, from complete beginners to seasoned skippers.
At the heart of our business, we’ve stayed true to our core values – particularly when it comes to customer service. From the very first call, guests are supported by expert holiday planners, who have sailed in the waters they’re recommending. This is a deliberate choice – we want our guests to feel confident knowing they’re speaking to someone with real, first-hand knowledge. That personalised service continues throughout the holiday experience, thanks to our base managers and local lead crews, who have the local insight and ability to make every guest feel supported and welcome.”
What do the next 50 years hold for Sunsail?
“The next 50 years are all about sustainability and innovation. We’re standing on the brink of real change in the yachting world – in how hulls are built, how boats are powered, and how we protect marine ecosystems. We want to lead that charge.
“Through our charitable partners and award-winning internal sustainability initiatives, we’re already laying the groundwork. We’re also exploring how to work more responsibly with local communities in every destination we operate.
“From a design perspective, we’ll continue to collaborate with top manufacturers to stay at the forefront of yacht innovation. Listening to our guests is key – they help us find that sweet spot where comfort, performance and sociability meet.”
Sunsail’s journey from a humble flotilla in the Saronic Gulf to a global sailing holiday pioneer is more than a business success story – it’s a celebration to a vision dedicated to a genuine love for life on the water.
Speaking with Clive, it’s clear that while the fleet, destinations, and technology have evolved, Sunsail’s core purpose has not wavered. As the brand looks ahead to the next 50 years, one thing is certain – the spirit that launched seven Snapdragons in 1974 still guides every voyage today.

Weymouth’s WASZP Games 2025: Largest Single Class Foiling Event Ever
With nearly 250 boats on the start line, the WASZP Games in Weymouth this summer, now stands as the largest single class foiling event ever writes Sue Pelling.
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
8 October 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
WASZP Games  |  Photo credit: Down Under Sail
In a week of mixed wind conditions peaking at 28-30kts on the first day, and then ranging from 12-13kts to the low 20s for the rest of the week, the
WASZP Games
at Weymouth and
Portland National Sailing Academy
(WPNSA) – which saw a record-breaking 248-strong entry – was deemed a huge success.
After an immensely close-fought series, it was Italian sailor Federico Bergamasco, and American Pearl Lattanzi who stole the show to take overall wins in the Men’s and Women’s Gold Fleet finals respectively, thus deeming them the 2025 WASZP Games overall champions. In the Gold fleet Bergamasco also proved that consistency was the name of the game because he won the title without winning a single race!
WASZP Games  |  Photo credit: Down Under Sail
Commenting on his overall win after the final race, a delighted Bergamasco said: “It’s been an amazing week with super racing. There was a lot of pressure on today [final day] because we all wanted to win. Staying in the top five was everything, so I had to fight with these amazing guys – Pablo [Astiazaran Pérez-Cela], Antonio [Gasperini], and Gavin [Ball] – to stay on top.”
Lattanzi chatting about her overall win, added: “I’m so happy. I don’t even know what to say. It doesn’t feel real now. The qualifying was pretty windy for me, so I was so happy to qualify for the Gold fleet. It was the most boats I’d ever raced against in a fleet and it was really competitive racing.”
With three main classes – determined by rig size – 8.2, 7.5 and 6.9, plus a smaller 5.8 (WASZP X) – the event attracted a huge, diverse fleet ranging from foiling demons including youngsters, women, to 50+ Super Masters. Each fleet raced early rounds to qualify for the finals within the Gold, Silver and Bronze fleets, so effectively there were three overall champions within the fleets.
WASZP Games Weymouth  |  Photo credit: Down Under Sail
Andrew McDougall – the WASZP designer, and a Super Master 50+, flying the flag for Australia – fought off some equally tough competition to take the Bronze championship title with three wins to count, from British sailor Pia Raber (Junior Under 19). Another top British finisher was Ben Harris (Core 21-29 year old) who sailed impressively to take second place overall in the Silver fleet.
It was good to see so many women taking the plunge to compete equally with the men. A total of 18% of the fleet were women and it was another Italian – Olivia Castaldi – who won the 6.9 division overall, while Lattanzi secured her overall win by finishing a creditable 34th in the final 70-strong Gold fleet. The top British-placed woman was Chloe Collenette who was 44th in the Silver fleet.
In keeping with the WASZP class’ ethos of inclusivity, there was also a category for total foiling beginners – the Green Fleet – with 10 in the fleet ranging from a 12 year old to 60+ club sailors enjoying a fun week of coaching and racing. Some of the youth sailors progressed so fast in the first couple of days, they made the decision to join the main 6.9 fleet for the rest of the week.
Martin Evans – WASZP Class Manager said the ‘Green Fleet was a huge success: “It helped newcomers to the fleet experience the Games with the chance to step up to the main fleet. The daily debriefs, tech talks, yoga, music and socials added real value and made the whole Games a fun and rewarding place to be.”
As an older sailor new to the WASZP, Derek Stannett (Super Master division 50+) said he found the Green Fleet experience invaluable. “It got me onto the water in an environment that was directly linked to the main event where I could learn from experienced coaches as well as observe other sailors, both in the Green fleet and beyond…My confidence improved dramatically during the week, heightening my enthusiasm for future events. It was also fantastic to make a group of new friends who I will hopefully see at future events and progress with.”
At the other end of the age spectrum, Alice Pope (18) another new-comer said the Green Fleet was a real confidence-builder: “I basically learnt how to sail a WASZP! By the end of the week we were all doing races and attempting foiling gybes. This gave me confidence that after some more practice I would be able to compete in some of the winter events in the 7.5 fleet in the UK.”
As well as the well-organised racing, it is the camaraderie and social side of any championship that helps to determine its success, so it wasn’t surprising to see the WASZP Games scoring top marks on all accounts. Duncan Hepplewhite – acting UK class chairman and director of
Sailingfast
(UK & Ireland Distributors for the WASZP) said the week was full on: “Social events are a big part of the Games and for this event, we even ran a special Masters’ evening at the local Bee Hive community-run cafe, for example. We also had some elite sailors from the Youth America’s Cup, all WASZP sailors who’d progressed to the America’s Cup, who came along and ran a presentation with a question and answer session. The big event of the week of course, was overall prizegiving, which was a Champagne spread in the sun with a Formula 1-style presentation.”
WASZP Games prize giving  |  Photo credit: Down Under Sail
Rounding up a successful event, Evans added: “The WASZP Games was an unbelievable experience for the sailors but equally for me as an organiser. It was a ‘pinch yourself moment’ on day one, when all the sails with flags and colours went up in the boat park and WPNSA was suddenly overrun with 248 WASZPs! We had spectacular racing every day despite imperfect wind conditions in the second half of the week, and the famous WASZP culture always shone throughout.”
Looking forward to next year’s events and beyond, Evans concluded: “In 2026 we’ll be heading to Pensacola [Florida] for the Games, which will be the first time for the event in the Americas. We also have the 2026 Europeans in Mar Menor, Murcia, Spain in July which I expect to top 200 boats, and we have some big news on the horizon for 2027.”

Following the journeys of the most travelled superyachts in 2025
8 January 2026 •
by Gabrielle Lazaridis
Driven by a keen desire to see the world, the superyacht fleet continues to travel near and far in search of exotic islands, intimate wildlife encounters or even just a slice of "la dolce vita" in the summertime. According to
BOATPro
's Global Fleet Tracker, more than 6,700 superyachts racked up a cumulative 20,963,247 nautical miles during 2025, showing an increase in traffic from last year's total distance of 19,894,029 nautical miles.
Wondering which ones went the furthest? BOATPro takes an inside look at what the top 10 most travelled yachts got up to over the past year...

First 36m Sirena Yachts flagship model on track for 2026 delivery
13 January 2026
• Written by Emily Dawkins
Turkish shipyard
Sirena Yachts
has announced that construction is steadily progressing on its first 36-metre Sirena 118 superyacht model. Major technical and interior milestones have now been completed and the superyacht is on track for her scheduled 2026 delivery.
According to the shipyard, works are now progressing on all plumbing, piping and technical installations alongside the production of teak decking and paint preparation. The new build will then undergo engine installation, paint completion and interior joinery ahead of her launch, sea trials and handover this year.
The model – penned by Sirena’s in-house design team – was first unveiled at the 2024
Monaco Yacht Show
as the largest in the shipyard’s composite line, built entirely in GRP with a sub-300GT volume and a flexible tri-deck layout.
7 images
Dutch designer
Cor D. Rover
is the brain behind the model's customisable interior design, which is said by the yard to be "contemporary-styled" and "highly elegant". Rover has used an "understated yet elegant" colour scheme, wood veneer applications and integrated soft lighting to create a sophisticated yet inviting ambience.
Cream upholstery, light wood tones and bronze accents characterise the decor - also chosen to help accentuate the spaces’ natural light, which, according to the yard, evolves from day to night with the glow from the rising to the setting sun.
Accommodation is for up to 12 guests and seven crew on board, with the guest accommodation comprising a VIP suite and four guest cabins on the lower deck. The shipyard has dedicated significant attention to the owner's area, which is located forward on the main deck and can extend across two decks in a "loft" option. A spiral staircase connects to a private relaxation space on the lower deck, which features a fold-down balcony.
There are plenty of social areas across the model's design, including an informal dining and lounging area on the main deck aft, outfitted with curvaceous contemporary furniture and curated fittings, while further dining and a wet bar can be found on the upper deck. Meanwhile, a Jacuzzi sits in the yacht's bow, flanked by sunpads and loungers.
With naval architecture by respected Argentinian naval architect
Germán Frers
, a fast displacement hull will give her a top speed of 16 knots, propelled by twin MAN V12 3,100hp engines. With a more powerful 3,800hp package, she will deliver a top speed of 21 knots.
“As the first Sirena 118 continues to take shape, we are proud to see the design vision materialising across every area of the build,” shared Sirena Yachts CEO, Çağin Genc. “The craftsmanship of our team, together with our long-standing partners such as Cor D. Rover and Germán Frers, is bringing this new flagship to life in a way that truly reflects the spirit of Sirena.”
The Turkish yard is also working towards the completion of its flagship yacht – created in collaboration with
Luca Vallebona
and
Hot Lab
– which is currently under construction in Yalova, Turkey, with delivery also scheduled for 2026.

Oyster Yachts reports improved FY25 results amid turnaround plan
8 January 2026 •
by Gabrielle Lazaridis
Oyster Yachts
is reporting noticeable improvements in its financial performance for the fiscal year (FY) ended 31 March 2025.
Within the past 12 months, the British shipyard saw a moderate increase in revenue, from £61.7 million in FY24 to £65.6 million, along with a 158 per cent surge in gross profit, which reached £10 million in FY25. The yard's gross profit margin increased from six per cent to 15 per cent during the same period.

DOM155: Baglietto unveils 46m flagship DOM line yacht model
13 January 2026
• Written by Emily Dawkins
Italian yard
Baglietto
has unveiled a new flagship addition to its successful DOM superyacht line: the DOM155. The first 46.4-metre unit will be available in early 2029.
The new model comes as an evolution of the popular 40.9-metre DOM133 line, which has 12 units sold, and the 34.5-metre DOM115 line, which has four new build orders to date. Characterised by a sub-500GT volume, the new displacement motor yacht follows the previous models' Roman domus concept of "warm, welcoming and refined", now expanded with larger volumes and "enhanced liveability".
Italian designer and long-time Baglietto collaborator
Stefano Vafiadis
has returned for the design of the DOM155. Vafiadis describes the design as “clean and sculptural," while “never excessive, yet balanced and aggressive at the same time, featuring longitudinal cuts and taut volumes inspired by automotive design.”
Taking inspiration from the DOM133, the DOM155 features generous volumes, floor-to-ceiling glazing and a "seamless dialogue" between interior and exterior spaces.
The main focus of the model is found in the stern. Dedicated to relaxation and well-being, the space features a central panoramic infinity pool with steps on either side leading to the aft cockpit. This space can be configured with a spa and gym overlooking the sea, thanks to a fold-down port-side shell door, or as an additional tender garage if desired.
The aft swimming platform also features a large transformer for swimming and easy dock access
Inside, living areas comprise a main deck saloon with a dining table for ten guests aft, and an upper deck saloon which opens on three sides for panoramic views. Also on the main deck is the owner's suite, which spans the yacht's full beam and is fitted with a walk-in closet, a master bedroom with a California king-size bed and a spacious his-and-hers en suite with a "walk-through" shower.
Four en suite guest cabins are located on the lower deck, forward of which is accommodation for a crew of eight in addition to a crew mess and laundry area. An additional guest cabin can also be incorporated on the upper deck if desired.
Other lounge spaces on board can be found forward of the wheelhouse (near a technical area housing a tender and jet ski) and a 130-square-metre sundeck fitted with sunbathing areas, a "conversation lounge" and an infinity pool with an integrated bar.
4 images
The latest DOM 133 yacht
Sui Generis
was launched in July 2025
In keeping with the DOM133, aluminium has been chosen as the construction material for the DOM155, allowing for greater customisation alongside improved performance and a shallow draught. As such, the project is particularly appealing to the American market, of which the La Spezia–based shipyard notes as one of its most important markets.
“The DOM155 is the result of listening carefully to our clients and, more broadly, to the market, which has enthusiastically welcomed both the 35- and 41-metre models but has repeatedly expressed interest in larger dimensions,” explained Baglietto’s chief commercial officer, Fabio Ermetto.
He continued: “This project, developed together with architect Stefano Vafiadis, brings together many of the improvement suggestions and experiences shared by our owners over the years, resulting in a yacht with high levels of customisation, comfort, and liveability that we are confident will fit perfectly into the sub-500 GT yacht segment.”
The DOM155 will be powered by twin CAT C32 engines, capable of reaching a 16-knot maximum speed.
According to
BOATPro
, Baglietto currently has 18 yachts on order or under construction, including three 60-metre T60 yacht models.

Saudi Red Sea Authority launches official guide for coastal tourism
7 January 2026 •
by Gabrielle Lazaridis
The Saudi Red Sea Authority (SRSA) has released the Introductory Guide to Coastal Tourism Activities, marking a "first of its kind" digital gateway to help grow the sector.
The guide streamlines all relevant information, regulations and procedures into a single, centralised electronic reference for tourists, investors and practitioners. It has been designed to shorten processing timelines and transform the information-seeking journey into a smooth, reliable and fully integrated digital experience. The guide also includes a comprehensive FAQ section, along with clear, advisory-based guidance outlining permitted and prohibited practices.
The first series of the guide is dedicated to yachting activities, offering a clear and practical end-to-end pathway for a yacht’s journey from arrival to departure. This includes procedures, documentation, licenses and permits, mechanisms for identifying and confirming the port of entry (port/marina) through a licensed agent, as well as directories of approved service providers (maritime tourism agents, yacht charter companies and marinas). It also includes safety and environmental sustainability guidelines, alongside periodic updates of regulatory requirements.
AMAALA Triple Bay
"The significance of the guide stems from its role as a foundational enabler for the coastal tourism activities sector, one of the key drivers of tourism growth," the SRSA stated. "Its launch is the result of intensive coordination efforts led by the Authority in collaboration with relevant entities to ensure role integration, foster an attractive tourism and investment environment, support the sector’s accelerating growth and align with the objectives of Saudi Vision 2030."
The announcement forms part of a broader effort to enhance yachting activity within Saudi Arabia and the Red Sea.
BOATPro
recently spoke with the CEO of the Saudi Tourism Authority (STA) to learn more about the country’s bold plans for transforming the yachting landscape and the future of tourism in the region.

Privacy Policy
We are committed to safeguarding your privacy. This Policy explains how we collect and use personal information.
Please read the following carefully to understand our views and practices regarding your personal data and how we will treat it. By visiting
www.seatalk.com
you are accepting and consenting to the practices described in this policy.
For the purpose of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (GDPR), the data controller is Gary Ritchie.
To contact the data protection officer you should email
[email protected]
.
References to ‘we’, ‘our’ and ‘us’ within this Privacy Policy are to Sea Talk Systems Ltd.
The information we collect
This Policy applies to information you give us, through our website or by corresponding with us and information collected by us as you visit or interact with our website.
The data you provide may include:
Your name
Your email
Your contact details
The data we collect about you may include, but is not limited to:
Your IP address
Information about your browser and operating system
Information about your visit, this may include, but is not limited to, pages looked at, visit duration, errors encountered and interaction with the pages.
How we use your information
Any personal information we collect from this website is used in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679) and other applicable laws.
The information you provide allows us to do the following:
If you have made an enquiry then we will use your contact details to respond to your enquiry.
If you opted in to our newsletter then we send you our newsletter.
To provide you with the information, products and services that you request from us.
To notify you about changes to our services.
To protect keep our website safe and secure.
To improve our website and personalise it for you and your computer.
To provide an efficient service, certain functions such as hosting, storage and disaster recovery are provided by third parties.
To provide interactive features.
To measure the effectiveness of our advertising.
It is our policy to ensure that your personal data is not made accessible to unauthorised individuals. We have taken reasonable steps to protect both the digital and physical storage of data.
We strive to protect your personal information, we cannot ensure or warrant the security of any information you transmit to us and you do so at your own risk.
Your data may be kept if it is required for legal or accounting reasons.
Disclosure of your information
Analytics and search engines providers that assist us in the improvement and optimisation of our site may collect data about your IP and computer set up.
How long do we keep your data
We will not retain your personal information longer than necessary.
If legally required or if it is reasonably necessary to meet regulatory requirements, resolve disputes, prevent fraud and abuse, or enforce our Terms and Conditions, we may also retain some of your information for a limited period of time as required, even after it is no longer needed to provide services to you.
Cookies
Cookies are small pieces of information that are stored by your browser on your device's hard-drive. They are used to distinguish individual users, and help us improve our website.
We explain how we use cookies in our
cookies policy
.
Access to your personal information
If you would like to update or remove the data we have about you please submit a request to the data protection officer.
If you wish to unsubscribe from our email newsletter you should use the unsubscribe link at the bottom of the email. Should this not work please contact the data protection officer, using the details at the start of this policy.
If you would like to request access to the data we have about you please submit a request to the data protection officer.
If an access request is deemed by us to be unfounded or excessive we may charge a reasonable fee. If you request further copies of your data then we may charge for administrative fees.
Complaints
If you wish to make a complaint about our use of your data please contact the data protection officer.
Updates to this policy
This Policy was last updated in March 2018.
Any changes we make to this policy will be posted to this page.

Sea Talk
TECHNOLOGIES DE CONNEXION
POUR L’INDUSTRIE SOUS-MARINE
ANTÉCÉDENTS ÉPROUVÉS
DE LIVRAISON DANS
LES DÉLAIS AVEC ZÉRO DÉFAUTS
Sea Talk Systems est le fournisseur indépendant agréé de kits UJ et UQJ, équipements et kits d’outils aux membres du Consortium UJ
Sea Talk Systems est une équipe très soudée de professionnels dont la plupart sont forts de plusieurs décennies d'expérience de la fourniture de kits et pièces destinés à l’industrie des câbles sous-marins.
Ils comprennent l’importance d’une fiabilité totale des pièces, kits et équipements, et connaissent les coûts énormes des défaillances. C’est pourquoi ils utilisent des processus stricts pour éliminer le risque de défaillances, et leurs excellents résultats en disent long sur le travail attentif de toute l’équipe.
La formation est l’un des pilliers de l’entreprise et STS s’assure continuellement que son équipe utilise les techniques les plus précises et les meilleurs équipements. Tous les membres de l’équipe sont polyvalents et cette flexibilité leur permet de diriger leurs efforts vers la tâche à réaliser afin de respecter les délais des commandes.
L’équipe de gestion a été formée pour savoir comment réaliser tous les processus nécessaires. Elle possède ainsi les informations nécessaires pour apporter des améliorations tant au niveau de la fiabilité qu’à celui de l’efficacité, tout en sachant identifier les éventuels risques à atténuer. C’est grâce à cette compréhension extrêmement détaillée de tous les aspects de l’entreprise que l’équipe réussit à maintenir ses antécédents de fiabilité à 100 % et de livraison dans les délais.
Contrôle Qualité
Contrôle Qualité
Kits UJ & UQJ
Kits UJ & UQJ
Contact
Contact
STS travaille avec un modèle commercial d’inspection intégrale qu’il a hérité quand l’activité a été transférée de Cable & Wireless Marine à STS. Le maintien de ce modèle commercial continue à garantir des kits et pièces de qualité et sans défauts dans cette industrie où la qualité est cruciale.
Dans ce secteur, une seule défaillance peut entraîner des pertes de revenus de centaines de milliers par jour si le système ne fonctionne pas. Sans mentionner le coût de la redirection du trafic, la location d’urgence de navires câbliers, la mise en place du personnel de jonctionnement, l’atteinte à votre réputation et à la confiance des clients.
Les raisons principales de la défaillance des systèmes sont généralement les bateaux de pêche, les ancres des navires, les séismes, les tsunamis et les courants de marée. STS est fier de garantir que les réparations ou nouveaux kits nécessaires sont fournis dans les délais, avec zéro défaut et aptes à l’utilisation.
STS occupe une installation ultra-moderne construite spécialement et dotée des équipements et contrôles de processus les plus récents.
